headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Centene Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter and Full Year Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ed Kroll, Senior Vice Presi
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Centene Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter and Full Year Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Ed Kroll, Senior Vice President of Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Emily, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2015 fourth quarter and full year earnings results conference call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Scheffel, Executive Vice President and Chief
componenttext:
Thank you, Emily, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2015 fourth quarter and full year earnings results conference call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Scheffel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Centene, will host this morning's call. 
The call should last approximately 45 minutes and may also be accessed through our website at centene.com. A replay will be available shortly after the call's completion, also at centene.com or by dialing (877) 344-7529 in the U.S. and Canada or in other countries by dialing (412) 317-0088. The playback number for both dial-ins is 10078696. 
Any remarks that Centene may make about future expectations, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provision under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by these forward-looking statements as a result of various important factors, including those discussed in Centene's most recently filed Form 10-K from February 23, 2015, and 10-Q from -- dated October 27, 2015. Centene's Registration Statement on Form S-4 relating to the proposed Health Net transaction, dated September 21, 2015, and in other public SEC filings. 
Centene anticipates that subsequent events and developments will cause its estimates to change. While the Company may elect to update these forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so. 
As a reminder, our next Investor Day is June 17 in New York City. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Michael Neidorff. Michael?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call. I'd like to begin with an update on the status of the Health Net acquisition. We have made significant progress towards completing
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call. I'd like to begin with an update on the status of the Health Net acquisition. We have made significant progress towards completing this transaction. We have received all necessary approvals, with the exception in California, which remains pending. On January 22, Centene participated in a public hearing with the California Department of Insurance. We believe the meeting was informative, and there were no surprises. It was conducted in a professional and respectful manner, and was part of what has been a fair, thorough process. We continue to work through the process with the Department of Insurance and the Department of Managed Health Care and are finalizing our mutual agreements. We remain confident of a first quarter close. We have slightly adjusted our 2016 guidance to reflect a March 1 closing date for Health Net. Jeff will provide further details on this. 
I would like to take a moment to remind you of the rationale behind the Health Net acquisition. It is a significant step in our strategy to build critical mass and expertise within the government-sponsored healthcare category. When the deal closes, Centene will be a $40-plus billion company. We will be the largest Medicaid managed care organization in the country and the leader in managed long-term support services. The addition of Health Net's Medicare Advantage platform, including its four-star rating, creates numerous opportunities within our existing markets, which we estimate to be in excess of $150 million. Health Net will increase our market presence to 15 states with total membership of approximately 500,000 individuals. There are significant opportunities to deploy Centene's specialty solutions across the Health Net platforms. Health Net has been an innovator in value-based provider contracting and risk-sharing systems. Finally, the deal is 20% accretive in adjusted EPS in the first year following the close. 
The planning portion of Centene's comprehensive integration process is now largely completed. We have reorganized our management team to facilitate collaboration and efficiency. We will be ready to hit the ground running to begin executing the plan on the day it closes. 
Now shifting to fourth quarter and full year 2015 highlights. Centene ended 2015 in a strong, balanced and secure structural and financial position. What do I mean by this? Several months ago, when I questioned a single contract in one state, Bill Scheffel, our CFO for the next few days, commented, "We are an aircraft carrier, and you don't throw aircraft carriers off course very easily." Today, we are in 23 states, soon to be 24 with Nebraska. In these 23 states, we have 231 separate solutions, which are products or contracts. This diversity provides strength and stability. In other words, if one product in one state has an issue, rate, something of that nature, there are more than enough offset. Many of you will recognize that this has been our strategy from the beginning. 
Clearly, 2015 was a banner year for Centene. Our long-term growth strategy is intact. We continue to execute against our pipeline as evidenced by recent wins in Florida and Nebraska. We added over 1 million members, representing growth of 26% to 5.1 million beneficiaries. Premium and Service revenues increased 36% year-over-year to $21.3 billion. The HBR improved 40 basis points year-over-year to 88.9%. We reported diluted earnings per share of $2.89 or $3.03 when excluding $0.14 of Health Net merger-related expenses. This compares to $2.23 reported for full year 2014. The pretax margin, excluding merger costs, improved to 3.4% from 2.9% in 2014 and 2.6% in 2013. We remain committed to margin and future margin expansion with a targeted range of 3% to 5%. Bill will provide further financial details in his prepared remarks. 
A quick note on flu. Current indicators point to a slower start to the 2015-2016 flu season. It is, however, still too early to draw an absolute conclusion. Overall, we continue to see as well as anticipate stable medical cost trends. 
Next, market and product updates. First, we'll discuss recent Medicaid activity. 
Nebraska. We were pleased to be selected last week as 1 of 3 managed care organizations to administer Nebraska's Heritage Health program. Heritage Health is a new healthcare delivery system that combines the state's current physical health, behavioral Health and pharmacy programs, into a single comprehensive and coordinated system. This program covers 230 Medicaid and CHIP enrollees. Centene will operate statewide in Nebraska, which marks our 24th state of operations. The contract is expected to commence on January 1, 2017, and we expect a normal margin ramp. This entry point provides future opportunities in the state, such as long-term care. 
Arizona. The fourth quarter was our first full quarter providing services under the expanded contract for Arizona's newly formed southern region. Membership in Arizona doubled over the third quarter of 2015. At December 31, we served approximately 441,000 beneficiaries in the state. 
Mississippi. Mississippi became a $1 billion market for Centene in 2015. In December, we began managing inpatient services for Medicaid and ABD members in the state. We ended the year with 302,000 lives. This compares to 109,000 at the end of 2014. 
Louisiana. Louisiana also became a $1 billion market in 2015. During the year, we executed a successful acquisition and integration in the state. We more than doubled our at-risk membership to 382,000 lives. In December, we further expanded our Louisiana contract to begin including behavioral health benefits. The carve-in of additional benefits in Mississippi and Louisiana is consistent with Centene's holistic approach to provide integrated care for its members. 
Oregon. The fourth quarter marked the first full quarter of operations for our Trillium subsidiary, which provides Medicaid, Medicare Advantage and marketplace services to Oregon residents. Membership at year-end was approximately 100,000. While it's still early, Trillium is performing in line with our expectations. 
Now on to dual eligibles. We ended the fourth quarter with 26,300 members across our 5 dual demonstration contracts. We continue to work with our state providers and CMS to make these programs successful and sustainable. I remind you that we have always taken the view that the dual demonstration programs would not be a significant near-term growth driver for Centene. 
Next, Medicaid expansion. We ended 2015 with almost 450,000 Medicaid expansion members, more than double that at -- of what was at the end of 2014. In January, the Governor of Louisiana signed an executive order to expand Medicaid coverage under ACA by July 1, 2016. This represents a future growth opportunity for Centene, given our status as the largest Medicaid health plan in the state. We have not yet included the Louisiana expansion in our 2016 financial guidance. We will provide an update when additional information becomes available. 
Health Insurance Marketplaces. Our exchange experience continues to be favorable. 92% of our membership is subsidy-eligible, and we are achieving margins within our targeted range. We have taken a disciplined approach to pricing from day 1. In fact, the aggregate in each of Centene's states reflected a payable position for both 2014 and 2015 for the 3Rs program. This approach has allowed us to grow profitably from 75,000 members in 9 states in 2014 to over 146,000 members in 12 states in 2015. Please note we have not been impacted by special enrollment periods. 
For 2016, we expanded into a 13th state, New Hampshire. We have also increased our geographic footprint in certain of our other 12 states. Enrollment so far in 2016 is in line or ahead of expectations. The demographics of these new members are consistent with previous years and over 90% are subsidy-eligible. Our pricing and underwriting is also in line with prior years, and we are not reliant on risk orders. 
Centurion. We continue to successfully expand our correctional health business. Last week, Centurion reached a formal agreement with the Florida Department of Corrections to provide comprehensive healthcare services to over 70,000 inmates throughout the 3 regions. The contract was awarded through an accelerated GAAP procurement. It was structured as a cost-plus arrangement with a maximum $267 million in annual revenue. Centurion was the only awardee. This contract is expected to commence in the second quarter of 2016 and runs through January of 2018. 
Shifting gears, our rate outlook. The 2015 composite rate adjustment was approximately 1%, in line with our expectations. Composite rate adjustments have been consistent for the past few years. We expect a similar composite rate adjustment in 2016. 
In conclusion, our strong 2015 results reaffirm our growth momentum for 2016 and beyond. As we begin this new year, we are at a good place, both financially and strategically. With the additional products and capabilities Health Net provides, our growth pipeline is bigger than ever. We are well positioned to gain market share in the government-sponsored healthcare space, the fastest-growing category in the industry. 
Thank you for your interest in Centene. Before I turn the call over to Bill, I want to thank him for his years of dedicated service. As previously announced, he will be retiring at the end of the month after the K is filed. You will now witness part of that turnover. Bill will cover 2015 information, and Jeff will pick up and report information relative to 2016. 
Bill, I turn it over to you.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we will cover both our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. For the fourth quarter, Premium and Service revenues were $5.9 billion, an increase of 33% over the fourth quarter of 2014, and
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we will cover both our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. For the fourth quarter, Premium and Service revenues were $5.9 billion, an increase of 33% over the fourth quarter of 2014, and diluted earnings per share, excluding Health Net merger costs, were $0.95 compared to $0.87 last year. And as you will recall, last year's fourth quarter included a $0.24 benefit from recording the health insurer fee reimbursement for Texas for all of 2014 in the fourth quarter. 
Looking at the full year for 2015. Membership was 5.1 million members, an increase of 26% between years. Premium and Service revenues were $21.3 billion, an increase of 36%. Earnings from operations were $705 million, with increase of 52% and diluted earnings per share, excluding Health Net merger costs, was $3.03, an increase of 36% between years and well above our most recent guidance numbers of $2.90 to $2.94. In more detail, Premium and Service revenues grew by $1.4 billion in the fourth quarter year-over-year, primarily as a result of the expansions or new programs in many of our states. During the fourth quarter, [indiscernible] newly added revenue in several areas. We began and expanded contract in the southern region of Arizona on October 1, behavioral health services were carved-in in Louisiana, beginning December 1. Inpatient services were added in Mississippi beginning December 1. And the fourth quarter included a full quarter of operations in Oregon relating to our acquisition that closes end of September. We also benefited from the addition of almost 250,000 more Medicaid expansion members at this year-end compared to last year. 
During 2015, we recognized $344 million in revenue associated with the health insurer fee compared to $195 million in 2014. For both years, the revenue recorded covers virtually all of the health insurer fee on a grossed-up basis for tax purposes. 
Our health benefits ratio was 88.0% in fourth quarter of this year compared to 89.3% in last year's fourth quarter and 89.0% in the third quarter. The 130 basis point decrease year-over-year results from improvement in the overall HBR from higher acuity membership, particularly long-term care, premium increases and adjustments and a milder flu season in the fourth quarter of this year. Sequentially, the 100 basis point improvement in the third quarter reflects rate increases and adjustments received during the third and fourth quarters. For the fourth quarter, 20% of Premium and Service revenues came from new business compared to 30% in the fourth quarter of 2014. The health benefits ratio of our new business was 88.2% and existing business was 88.0% in the fourth quarter, both of which are decreases of 120 basis points between years. 
The health insurance marketplace product has performed well for us in 2014 and 2015, reflecting our disciplined strategy to focus on subsidized members familiar with our provider network. This same methodology and process was used for 2016 as well. Similar to last year-end, we continue to be in a payable position for the risk corridor and risk adjustment components of the 3Rs. And we also have a payable at year-end recorded for the minimum loss ratio for the Health Insurance Marketplace business. For the 2014 plan year, we have settled the 3R amounts and paid the rebates related to the minimum loss ratio. 
Our general and administrative expense ratio was 8.8% in Q4 of this year, 8.7% without Health Net merger cost, compared to 8.2% last year and 8.2% in the third quarter, also excluding Health Net merger cost. The increase in the fourth quarter of this year, both year-over-year and sequentially, reflects a higher level of seasonal costs related to the open enrollment period for the marketplace exchange product and higher amounts of variable compensation products. Excluding Health Net merger costs, business expansion costs of $.07 were incurred in the fourth quarter and $0.23 for all of 2015. 
Investment and other income was $8 million for the fourth quarter compared to $10 million last year and $8 million in the third quarter. Interest expense was $11 million this year compared to $10 million last year and $11 million in the third quarter. Our effective income tax rate was 48.4% in the fourth quarter and 48.6% for all of 2015. The relatively high rate reflects the nondeductible nature of the health insurer fee. 
Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations for the fourth quarter was $0.91, $0.95 excluding the Health Net merger cost. For the full year 2015, our EPS was $2.89 or $3.03 excluding the merger cost. 
Cash and investments totaled almost $4 billion at year-end, including $78 million held by unregulated subsidiaries, and our risk-based capital percentage continues to be in excess of 350% of the authorized control level. 
Debt on December 31 was $1.2 billion, including $225 million of borrowings on our revolver. Our debt-to-capital ratio was 34.7%, excluding our nonrecourse mortgage note compared to 71.7% at last year-end. Medical claims liability totaled $2.3 billion at December 31 and represent 44.3 days in claims payable. The cash flow from operations was $201 million in the fourth quarter and $658 million for the full year. Both amounts to approximate 1.8x net earnings, which is consistent with our expected range of 1.5 to 2.0x net earnings. 
Now for 2016, Jeff Schwaneke will discuss our 2016 guidance number for you.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning. I would like to spend a few minutes to discuss our combined guidance for 2016. In our press release this morning reporting our full year results for 2015, we've also included our 2016 annual guidance. The guidance has be
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning. I would like to spend a few minutes to discuss our combined guidance for 2016. In our press release this morning reporting our full year results for 2015, we've also included our 2016 annual guidance. The guidance has been adjusted for the following items: First, we have changed our assumption with respect to the closing date of the Health Net transaction. We are now assuming the transaction closes on March 1. While this does not impact our run rate revenues or earnings, it does change the number of months of Health Net we are able to include in the consolidated financial statements for 2016. As mentioned in our December Investor Day, 1 month of Health Net revenue is approximately $1.3 billion. The March 1 closing date is an assumption we have made for guidance purposes, and the transaction remains subject to regulatory approval in California. The actual closing date of the Health Net transaction will determine the number of months and days of Health Net results that will be included in our consolidated financial statements for 2016; second, we recently announced the pricing of $2.4 billion of senior unsecured debt in connection with the Health Net transaction and have updated our assumptions with respect to interest expense. Consistent with what we have done in the past in matching our balance sheet exposure to short-term interest rates, we intend to swap up to approximately $1.6 billion of the senior debt to a floating rate of interest at transaction closing. Since we have not entered into the interest rate swap agreements, the ultimate interest rate of the transaction financing will continue to fluctuate; third, we have adjusted our range on Health Net merger-related expenses, which will continue to change until closing, and have reduced the guidance range for the amortization of intangible assets associated with acquisitions by 1 month to reflect the assumed March 1 closing date. 
And finally, we have updated our guidance to include the recent contract award for Centurion in Florida. 
As a result of all these items for 2016, our combined guidance is as follows: total revenues of $40 billion to $40.8 billion; GAAP diluted earnings per share of $2.80 to $3.15; adjusted diluted earnings per share of $4.05 to $4.40; adjusted diluted earnings per share excludes the amortization of intangible assets associated with acquisitions, which we estimate to be between $0.50 and $0.55 per share, and Health Net related merger expenses, which we estimate to be between $0.70 and $0.75 per diluted share, with both items reflecting the revised closing date assumption. We have adjusted the bottom end of our diluted earnings per share guidance range to reflect the 1-month delay in the assumed closing date of the Health Net transaction. For 2016, we expect approximately 45% of our annual adjusted diluted earnings per share to be earned in the first half of the year, and we expect the first quarter to be lower than the second quarter due to seasonality of the business, the extra day from leap year and only including 1 month of Health Net in our consolidated results for the first quarter. Additionally, our guidance assumes no receivables for the risk corridor program and a payable for the risk adjustment program in 2016. We will provide further details on our 2016 guidance after regulatory approval and the closing of the Health Net transaction. 
This concludes our remarks. Operator, you may now open the line for questions.

componenttext: Yes, you're correct. So obviously, we've already priced the debt, and I think what I'm saying today is that we are anticipating swapping up to $1.6 billion to a floating rate of interest consistent with what we've done in the past. Our current guidance does assume some blending form of the coupon plus the benefit of the swaps. Obviously, we wouldn't execute the swap transactions if they weren't beneficial. So I would say, right now, we believe we have a relatively conservative assumption based on where the spreads are on the swaps today.

componenttextpreview: And then just a second question. You guys have talked about this Medicare platform from Health Net as a new platform to expand Medicare into your markets. Then, it hadn't really been a growth business. They lost another 5%, maybe 20,000-plus lives accordi
componenttext: And then just a second question. You guys have talked about this Medicare platform from Health Net as a new platform to expand Medicare into your markets. Then, it hadn't really been a growth business. They lost another 5%, maybe 20,000-plus lives according to the CMS data in January. So I'm just curious what gives you confidence that, that becomes a growth platform, that you can kind of turn it around. And what exactly are you acquiring that gives you comfort that you're going to be able to become a larger MA player?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, one, we've indicated we're going to enter methodically, carefully. Initially, probably 3 new markets in January next year. We're not saying which ones for obvious competitive reasons. I think that the big differences that we've done -- and s
componenttext: Yes, I think, one, we've indicated we're going to enter methodically, carefully. Initially, probably 3 new markets in January next year. We're not saying which ones for obvious competitive reasons. I think that the big differences that we've done -- and some of us have done Medicare before, and they understand it, but they have some systems and capabilities. They have the 4 stars, which does give you a premium benefit for the first 2 years of 5%. And I think the major difference, Josh, is that there is a corporation now that has a commitment to build the systems and capabilities to continue to grow and expand the MA versus someone a company that was in a different mode in the middle of outsourcing, a lot of things, before the acquisition. So it's almost a mentality thing, I think is as much as anything it is. Very capable people there that are excited about what this opportunity working with us means.

componenttext: Sure. If you look at the quarter-over-quarter, we improved 130 basis points. We've also had the premium increases and adjustments that we received between year-over-year, particularly in some of our larger states. And then flu season was much lower this year than last year.

componenttextpreview: It's a combination of both. We get rate increases in 3 of our largest states in the second half of the year with Georgia on July 1 and Florida and Texas on September 1. And then there's also risk adjustments that are made periodically by the states, and t
componenttext: It's a combination of both. We get rate increases in 3 of our largest states in the second half of the year with Georgia on July 1 and Florida and Texas on September 1. And then there's also risk adjustments that are made periodically by the states, and those are going to be somewhat lumpy at times when those are actually provided to us. So the combination of all of those things gave us the overall rate improvement.

componenttext: I think we commented that, one, the growth is in line with what we expected. And you had the initial enrollment and those that actually pay the premium work through it. And hence, we've had a payable in all our states when you look at the -- those aspects from a consolidated basis within the states, and we see no reason why that's going to change. We maintained the same approach. We have the subsidy population. We commented in the script that the profile of the individuals we've enrolled are the same. And so it's a matter of we're into risk business, and it's called managing the risk.

componenttext: I appreciate the precision. In terms of comments on flu, are you assuming, in the early part of '16, that you may be making a conservative assumption about flu, "catching up"? And then what are your assumptions for the end of 2016 and flu season in the fourth quarter '16?

componenttextpreview: I think we see some indications of it ramping up at this point in time. So that's why I said it's too early to say that there's going to be no flu season at all this year. We've seen flu seasons come early. We've seen them come late. I would say on fourth
componenttext: I think we see some indications of it ramping up at this point in time. So that's why I said it's too early to say that there's going to be no flu season at all this year. We've seen flu seasons come early. We've seen them come late. I would say on fourth quarter, and Jeff can confirm this, but we have booked the normal flu range that we do as we did in every quarter. And it's not the high end or the low end, it's what we reasonably expect it to be.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Peter Costa of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of, let me say thanks and congratulations, Bill. You did great job for us and for Centene. And good luck, Jeff, going forward. And that gets me on my question, which is really about reserves for the company and days and claims payable. What do you e
componenttext: First of, let me say thanks and congratulations, Bill. You did great job for us and for Centene. And good luck, Jeff, going forward. And that gets me on my question, which is really about reserves for the company and days and claims payable. What do you expect days and claims payable to do this year, given all the moving parts with sort of less new business and Health Net coming on board? What should we be expecting to see in the days claims payable?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jeff. I mean, we -- as far as on a combined basis with Health Net, we haven't given out anything on that as far as Centene is concerned. I think we have a range from the 40 -- low 40s to mid 40s, I would still expect to be in that range. I do
componenttext: Yes, this is Jeff. I mean, we -- as far as on a combined basis with Health Net, we haven't given out anything on that as far as Centene is concerned. I think we have a range from the 40 -- low 40s to mid 40s, I would still expect to be in that range. I don't see anything unusual happening there. I think the biggest thing that impacts that is the how fast we receive claims and the EDI rate that we have, and we have continued to see an increase in the EDI rate. And so over time, you'd expect that to reduce your days and claims payable. But nothing significant that I would expect.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] important I have said probably in many presentations and meetings that we are averaging 98-plus percent, 98.6% payment in 6 to 8 days or less when the dates of claims comes in. We have a 99% accuracy within the payment of those claims. So
componenttext: [indiscernible] important I have said probably in many presentations and meetings that we are averaging 98-plus percent, 98.6% payment in 6 to 8 days or less when the dates of claims comes in. We have a 99% accuracy within the payment of those claims. So you put all those kinds of factors together, it gives you a high degree of confidence in your lag [ph] tables and those factors and the greatest impact, as Jeff highlighted, will be as claims continue to come in faster, that's the variable. And when you have a constant on the other end of it, that says you don't have to measure as many different, and we use a date receive methodology. So if claims start to come in faster or more of them, then we have 2 out of the 3 factors that are constant.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Should we expect any sort of slowdown as you bring on the Health Net systems and then platform onto your servers?
componenttext: Should we expect any sort of slowdown as you bring on the Health Net systems and then platform onto your servers?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me tell you that we have stated that we're going to be very methodical in bringing on -- because we've seen -- too many times when people try to do it quickly, and they throw the switch and the lights dim. We're going to avoid that. We've stated
componenttext: Well, let me tell you that we have stated that we're going to be very methodical in bringing on -- because we've seen -- too many times when people try to do it quickly, and they throw the switch and the lights dim. We're going to avoid that. We've stated that we anticipate it's going to take 2 years to fully integrate all the systems. They were in the middle of a lot of outsourcing, that's all coming back in. They have a lot of people offshore that will be coming back. So there's a lot of different aspects to it. So anticipate a couple of years, and we'll keep you informed on earnings calls how it's going.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, again, the most significant component of time on days and claims payable is how long it takes from the date of service to when we receive the claims, and that's the majority of the time, as Michael mentioned, how fast we actually process those paymen
componenttext: Yes, again, the most significant component of time on days and claims payable is how long it takes from the date of service to when we receive the claims, and that's the majority of the time, as Michael mentioned, how fast we actually process those payments once we receive the claim.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me -- we -- thank you for calling the disk drive issue. Because it's really a data issue in our case. There was no intrusion, there was no hacking. Appreciate the way you articulated it, it was very important. We continue down the process, we
componenttext: Yes, so let me -- we -- thank you for calling the disk drive issue. Because it's really a data issue in our case. There was no intrusion, there was no hacking. Appreciate the way you articulated it, it was very important. We continue down the process, we continue to look at it. We continue to apply an abundance of conservatism and transparency to it. Clearly, to this point, we have seen no hint or any indication of any inappropriate use of the data. And we are continuing the search and looking to see -- when we have 26,000 discs. And you're looking for 6, that's the proverbial needle in the haystack. And we're doing that methodically, again just to double check it. So there's no update beyond that. But as I said, we're following through. We're notifying everybody. And importantly, Steven, this data was an incredibly raw form. We're using it to line up the state's laboratory and other data. So it's not a very usable state. You really have to have a lot of our systems to get to it. But once again, as soon as we see something that could be an issue, our policy is to get it out there.

componenttextpreview: I mean what's important -- we -- and I've said this multiple times, in no way, at any time, for the past [indiscernible] demonstration have we looked to the dual product for any of our growth. We've recognized that it would be a very slow, difficult proce
componenttext: I mean what's important -- we -- and I've said this multiple times, in no way, at any time, for the past [indiscernible] demonstration have we looked to the dual product for any of our growth. We've recognized that it would be a very slow, difficult process the way we structured, with the opt-outs, et cetera. And for that reason, we've said from the beginning that it's just not something that we put a lot behind with. We're doing enough. And I think we've said at the Investor Day, we get to a high in total between the 2 companies to 50,000 or something. We're doing enough to demonstrate that we really know how to do it and do it well. So that when -- and we're working with the state issues that, in fact, the opt-out, so that when and if they decide to do something about it, we're in a strong position. And beyond that, I have no great expectations. And it's not going to make or break any state or any year for us.

componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Centene Corporation 2015 Fourth Quarter and Full Year Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Ed Kroll, Senior Vice President of Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Emily, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2015 fourth quarter and full year earnings results conference call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Scheffel, Executive Vice President and Chief
componenttext:
Thank you, Emily, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2015 fourth quarter and full year earnings results conference call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Bill Scheffel, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Centene, will host this morning's call. 
The call should last approximately 45 minutes and may also be accessed through our website at centene.com. A replay will be available shortly after the call's completion, also at centene.com or by dialing (877) 344-7529 in the U.S. and Canada or in other countries by dialing (412) 317-0088. The playback number for both dial-ins is 10078696. 
Any remarks that Centene may make about future expectations, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provision under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by these forward-looking statements as a result of various important factors, including those discussed in Centene's most recently filed Form 10-K from February 23, 2015, and 10-Q from -- dated October 27, 2015. Centene's Registration Statement on Form S-4 relating to the proposed Health Net transaction, dated September 21, 2015, and in other public SEC filings. 
Centene anticipates that subsequent events and developments will cause its estimates to change. While the Company may elect to update these forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so. 
As a reminder, our next Investor Day is June 17 in New York City. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Michael Neidorff. Michael?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call. I'd like to begin with an update on the status of the Health Net acquisition. We have made significant progress towards completing
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call. I'd like to begin with an update on the status of the Health Net acquisition. We have made significant progress towards completing this transaction. We have received all necessary approvals, with the exception in California, which remains pending. On January 22, Centene participated in a public hearing with the California Department of Insurance. We believe the meeting was informative, and there were no surprises. It was conducted in a professional and respectful manner, and was part of what has been a fair, thorough process. We continue to work through the process with the Department of Insurance and the Department of Managed Health Care and are finalizing our mutual agreements. We remain confident of a first quarter close. We have slightly adjusted our 2016 guidance to reflect a March 1 closing date for Health Net. Jeff will provide further details on this. 
I would like to take a moment to remind you of the rationale behind the Health Net acquisition. It is a significant step in our strategy to build critical mass and expertise within the government-sponsored healthcare category. When the deal closes, Centene will be a $40-plus billion company. We will be the largest Medicaid managed care organization in the country and the leader in managed long-term support services. The addition of Health Net's Medicare Advantage platform, including its four-star rating, creates numerous opportunities within our existing markets, which we estimate to be in excess of $150 million. Health Net will increase our market presence to 15 states with total membership of approximately 500,000 individuals. There are significant opportunities to deploy Centene's specialty solutions across the Health Net platforms. Health Net has been an innovator in value-based provider contracting and risk-sharing systems. Finally, the deal is 20% accretive in adjusted EPS in the first year following the close. 
The planning portion of Centene's comprehensive integration process is now largely completed. We have reorganized our management team to facilitate collaboration and efficiency. We will be ready to hit the ground running to begin executing the plan on the day it closes. 
Now shifting to fourth quarter and full year 2015 highlights. Centene ended 2015 in a strong, balanced and secure structural and financial position. What do I mean by this? Several months ago, when I questioned a single contract in one state, Bill Scheffel, our CFO for the next few days, commented, "We are an aircraft carrier, and you don't throw aircraft carriers off course very easily." Today, we are in 23 states, soon to be 24 with Nebraska. In these 23 states, we have 231 separate solutions, which are products or contracts. This diversity provides strength and stability. In other words, if one product in one state has an issue, rate, something of that nature, there are more than enough offset. Many of you will recognize that this has been our strategy from the beginning. 
Clearly, 2015 was a banner year for Centene. Our long-term growth strategy is intact. We continue to execute against our pipeline as evidenced by recent wins in Florida and Nebraska. We added over 1 million members, representing growth of 26% to 5.1 million beneficiaries. Premium and Service revenues increased 36% year-over-year to $21.3 billion. The HBR improved 40 basis points year-over-year to 88.9%. We reported diluted earnings per share of $2.89 or $3.03 when excluding $0.14 of Health Net merger-related expenses. This compares to $2.23 reported for full year 2014. The pretax margin, excluding merger costs, improved to 3.4% from 2.9% in 2014 and 2.6% in 2013. We remain committed to margin and future margin expansion with a targeted range of 3% to 5%. Bill will provide further financial details in his prepared remarks. 
A quick note on flu. Current indicators point to a slower start to the 2015-2016 flu season. It is, however, still too early to draw an absolute conclusion. Overall, we continue to see as well as anticipate stable medical cost trends. 
Next, market and product updates. First, we'll discuss recent Medicaid activity. 
Nebraska. We were pleased to be selected last week as 1 of 3 managed care organizations to administer Nebraska's Heritage Health program. Heritage Health is a new healthcare delivery system that combines the state's current physical health, behavioral Health and pharmacy programs, into a single comprehensive and coordinated system. This program covers 230 Medicaid and CHIP enrollees. Centene will operate statewide in Nebraska, which marks our 24th state of operations. The contract is expected to commence on January 1, 2017, and we expect a normal margin ramp. This entry point provides future opportunities in the state, such as long-term care. 
Arizona. The fourth quarter was our first full quarter providing services under the expanded contract for Arizona's newly formed southern region. Membership in Arizona doubled over the third quarter of 2015. At December 31, we served approximately 441,000 beneficiaries in the state. 
Mississippi. Mississippi became a $1 billion market for Centene in 2015. In December, we began managing inpatient services for Medicaid and ABD members in the state. We ended the year with 302,000 lives. This compares to 109,000 at the end of 2014. 
Louisiana. Louisiana also became a $1 billion market in 2015. During the year, we executed a successful acquisition and integration in the state. We more than doubled our at-risk membership to 382,000 lives. In December, we further expanded our Louisiana contract to begin including behavioral health benefits. The carve-in of additional benefits in Mississippi and Louisiana is consistent with Centene's holistic approach to provide integrated care for its members. 
Oregon. The fourth quarter marked the first full quarter of operations for our Trillium subsidiary, which provides Medicaid, Medicare Advantage and marketplace services to Oregon residents. Membership at year-end was approximately 100,000. While it's still early, Trillium is performing in line with our expectations. 
Now on to dual eligibles. We ended the fourth quarter with 26,300 members across our 5 dual demonstration contracts. We continue to work with our state providers and CMS to make these programs successful and sustainable. I remind you that we have always taken the view that the dual demonstration programs would not be a significant near-term growth driver for Centene. 
Next, Medicaid expansion. We ended 2015 with almost 450,000 Medicaid expansion members, more than double that at -- of what was at the end of 2014. In January, the Governor of Louisiana signed an executive order to expand Medicaid coverage under ACA by July 1, 2016. This represents a future growth opportunity for Centene, given our status as the largest Medicaid health plan in the state. We have not yet included the Louisiana expansion in our 2016 financial guidance. We will provide an update when additional information becomes available. 
Health Insurance Marketplaces. Our exchange experience continues to be favorable. 92% of our membership is subsidy-eligible, and we are achieving margins within our targeted range. We have taken a disciplined approach to pricing from day 1. In fact, the aggregate in each of Centene's states reflected a payable position for both 2014 and 2015 for the 3Rs program. This approach has allowed us to grow profitably from 75,000 members in 9 states in 2014 to over 146,000 members in 12 states in 2015. Please note we have not been impacted by special enrollment periods. 
For 2016, we expanded into a 13th state, New Hampshire. We have also increased our geographic footprint in certain of our other 12 states. Enrollment so far in 2016 is in line or ahead of expectations. The demographics of these new members are consistent with previous years and over 90% are subsidy-eligible. Our pricing and underwriting is also in line with prior years, and we are not reliant on risk orders. 
Centurion. We continue to successfully expand our correctional health business. Last week, Centurion reached a formal agreement with the Florida Department of Corrections to provide comprehensive healthcare services to over 70,000 inmates throughout the 3 regions. The contract was awarded through an accelerated GAAP procurement. It was structured as a cost-plus arrangement with a maximum $267 million in annual revenue. Centurion was the only awardee. This contract is expected to commence in the second quarter of 2016 and runs through January of 2018. 
Shifting gears, our rate outlook. The 2015 composite rate adjustment was approximately 1%, in line with our expectations. Composite rate adjustments have been consistent for the past few years. We expect a similar composite rate adjustment in 2016. 
In conclusion, our strong 2015 results reaffirm our growth momentum for 2016 and beyond. As we begin this new year, we are at a good place, both financially and strategically. With the additional products and capabilities Health Net provides, our growth pipeline is bigger than ever. We are well positioned to gain market share in the government-sponsored healthcare space, the fastest-growing category in the industry. 
Thank you for your interest in Centene. Before I turn the call over to Bill, I want to thank him for his years of dedicated service. As previously announced, he will be retiring at the end of the month after the K is filed. You will now witness part of that turnover. Bill will cover 2015 information, and Jeff will pick up and report information relative to 2016. 
Bill, I turn it over to you.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we will cover both our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. For the fourth quarter, Premium and Service revenues were $5.9 billion, an increase of 33% over the fourth quarter of 2014, and
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we will cover both our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. For the fourth quarter, Premium and Service revenues were $5.9 billion, an increase of 33% over the fourth quarter of 2014, and diluted earnings per share, excluding Health Net merger costs, were $0.95 compared to $0.87 last year. And as you will recall, last year's fourth quarter included a $0.24 benefit from recording the health insurer fee reimbursement for Texas for all of 2014 in the fourth quarter. 
Looking at the full year for 2015. Membership was 5.1 million members, an increase of 26% between years. Premium and Service revenues were $21.3 billion, an increase of 36%. Earnings from operations were $705 million, with increase of 52% and diluted earnings per share, excluding Health Net merger costs, was $3.03, an increase of 36% between years and well above our most recent guidance numbers of $2.90 to $2.94. In more detail, Premium and Service revenues grew by $1.4 billion in the fourth quarter year-over-year, primarily as a result of the expansions or new programs in many of our states. During the fourth quarter, [indiscernible] newly added revenue in several areas. We began and expanded contract in the southern region of Arizona on October 1, behavioral health services were carved-in in Louisiana, beginning December 1. Inpatient services were added in Mississippi beginning December 1. And the fourth quarter included a full quarter of operations in Oregon relating to our acquisition that closes end of September. We also benefited from the addition of almost 250,000 more Medicaid expansion members at this year-end compared to last year. 
During 2015, we recognized $344 million in revenue associated with the health insurer fee compared to $195 million in 2014. For both years, the revenue recorded covers virtually all of the health insurer fee on a grossed-up basis for tax purposes. 
Our health benefits ratio was 88.0% in fourth quarter of this year compared to 89.3% in last year's fourth quarter and 89.0% in the third quarter. The 130 basis point decrease year-over-year results from improvement in the overall HBR from higher acuity membership, particularly long-term care, premium increases and adjustments and a milder flu season in the fourth quarter of this year. Sequentially, the 100 basis point improvement in the third quarter reflects rate increases and adjustments received during the third and fourth quarters. For the fourth quarter, 20% of Premium and Service revenues came from new business compared to 30% in the fourth quarter of 2014. The health benefits ratio of our new business was 88.2% and existing business was 88.0% in the fourth quarter, both of which are decreases of 120 basis points between years. 
The health insurance marketplace product has performed well for us in 2014 and 2015, reflecting our disciplined strategy to focus on subsidized members familiar with our provider network. This same methodology and process was used for 2016 as well. Similar to last year-end, we continue to be in a payable position for the risk corridor and risk adjustment components of the 3Rs. And we also have a payable at year-end recorded for the minimum loss ratio for the Health Insurance Marketplace business. For the 2014 plan year, we have settled the 3R amounts and paid the rebates related to the minimum loss ratio. 
Our general and administrative expense ratio was 8.8% in Q4 of this year, 8.7% without Health Net merger cost, compared to 8.2% last year and 8.2% in the third quarter, also excluding Health Net merger cost. The increase in the fourth quarter of this year, both year-over-year and sequentially, reflects a higher level of seasonal costs related to the open enrollment period for the marketplace exchange product and higher amounts of variable compensation products. Excluding Health Net merger costs, business expansion costs of $.07 were incurred in the fourth quarter and $0.23 for all of 2015. 
Investment and other income was $8 million for the fourth quarter compared to $10 million last year and $8 million in the third quarter. Interest expense was $11 million this year compared to $10 million last year and $11 million in the third quarter. Our effective income tax rate was 48.4% in the fourth quarter and 48.6% for all of 2015. The relatively high rate reflects the nondeductible nature of the health insurer fee. 
Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations for the fourth quarter was $0.91, $0.95 excluding the Health Net merger cost. For the full year 2015, our EPS was $2.89 or $3.03 excluding the merger cost. 
Cash and investments totaled almost $4 billion at year-end, including $78 million held by unregulated subsidiaries, and our risk-based capital percentage continues to be in excess of 350% of the authorized control level. 
Debt on December 31 was $1.2 billion, including $225 million of borrowings on our revolver. Our debt-to-capital ratio was 34.7%, excluding our nonrecourse mortgage note compared to 71.7% at last year-end. Medical claims liability totaled $2.3 billion at December 31 and represent 44.3 days in claims payable. The cash flow from operations was $201 million in the fourth quarter and $658 million for the full year. Both amounts to approximate 1.8x net earnings, which is consistent with our expected range of 1.5 to 2.0x net earnings. 
Now for 2016, Jeff Schwaneke will discuss our 2016 guidance number for you.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning. I would like to spend a few minutes to discuss our combined guidance for 2016. In our press release this morning reporting our full year results for 2015, we've also included our 2016 annual guidance. The guidance has be
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning. I would like to spend a few minutes to discuss our combined guidance for 2016. In our press release this morning reporting our full year results for 2015, we've also included our 2016 annual guidance. The guidance has been adjusted for the following items: First, we have changed our assumption with respect to the closing date of the Health Net transaction. We are now assuming the transaction closes on March 1. While this does not impact our run rate revenues or earnings, it does change the number of months of Health Net we are able to include in the consolidated financial statements for 2016. As mentioned in our December Investor Day, 1 month of Health Net revenue is approximately $1.3 billion. The March 1 closing date is an assumption we have made for guidance purposes, and the transaction remains subject to regulatory approval in California. The actual closing date of the Health Net transaction will determine the number of months and days of Health Net results that will be included in our consolidated financial statements for 2016; second, we recently announced the pricing of $2.4 billion of senior unsecured debt in connection with the Health Net transaction and have updated our assumptions with respect to interest expense. Consistent with what we have done in the past in matching our balance sheet exposure to short-term interest rates, we intend to swap up to approximately $1.6 billion of the senior debt to a floating rate of interest at transaction closing. Since we have not entered into the interest rate swap agreements, the ultimate interest rate of the transaction financing will continue to fluctuate; third, we have adjusted our range on Health Net merger-related expenses, which will continue to change until closing, and have reduced the guidance range for the amortization of intangible assets associated with acquisitions by 1 month to reflect the assumed March 1 closing date. 
And finally, we have updated our guidance to include the recent contract award for Centurion in Florida. 
As a result of all these items for 2016, our combined guidance is as follows: total revenues of $40 billion to $40.8 billion; GAAP diluted earnings per share of $2.80 to $3.15; adjusted diluted earnings per share of $4.05 to $4.40; adjusted diluted earnings per share excludes the amortization of intangible assets associated with acquisitions, which we estimate to be between $0.50 and $0.55 per share, and Health Net related merger expenses, which we estimate to be between $0.70 and $0.75 per diluted share, with both items reflecting the revised closing date assumption. We have adjusted the bottom end of our diluted earnings per share guidance range to reflect the 1-month delay in the assumed closing date of the Health Net transaction. For 2016, we expect approximately 45% of our annual adjusted diluted earnings per share to be earned in the first half of the year, and we expect the first quarter to be lower than the second quarter due to seasonality of the business, the extra day from leap year and only including 1 month of Health Net in our consolidated results for the first quarter. Additionally, our guidance assumes no receivables for the risk corridor program and a payable for the risk adjustment program in 2016. We will provide further details on our 2016 guidance after regulatory approval and the closing of the Health Net transaction. 
This concludes our remarks. Operator, you may now open the line for questions.

componenttext: Yes, you're correct. Our current guidance does assume some blending form of the coupon plus the benefit of the swaps. Obviously, we wouldn't execute the swap transactions if they weren't beneficial. So I would say, right now, we believe we have a relatively conservative assumption based on where the spreads are on the swaps today.

componenttext: And then just a second question. You guys have talked about this Medicare platform from Health Net as a new platform to expand Medicare into your markets. Then, it hadn't really been a growth business. They lost another 5%, maybe 20,000-plus lives according to the CMS data in January. So I'm just curious what gives you confidence that, that becomes a growth platform, that you can kind of turn it around. And what exactly are you acquiring that gives you comfort that you're going to be able to become a larger MA player?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, one, we've indicated we're going to enter methodically, carefully. Initially, probably 3 new markets in January next year. We're not saying which ones for obvious competitive reasons. I think that the big differences that we've done -- and s
componenttext: Yes, I think, one, we've indicated we're going to enter methodically, carefully. Initially, probably 3 new markets in January next year. We're not saying which ones for obvious competitive reasons. I think that the big differences that we've done -- and some of us have done Medicare before, and they understand it, but they have some systems and capabilities. They have the 4 stars, which does give you a premium benefit for the first 2 years of 5%. And I think the major difference, Josh, is that there is a corporation now that has a commitment to build the systems and capabilities to continue to grow and expand the MA versus someone a company that was in a different mode in the middle of outsourcing, a lot of things, before the acquisition. So it's almost a mentality thing, I think is as much as anything it is. Very capable people there that are excited about what this opportunity working with us means.

componenttext: It's a combination of both. We get rate increases in 3 of our largest states in the second half of the year with Georgia on July 1 and Florida and Texas on September 1. Anything to go on there as far as [indiscernible] articles or trend that you would highlight into Q4 versus your expectations for the first 3 quarters?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I said [indiscernible] and add to it, if you wish, but I view that as an accounting issue. And I think our team here has, whether it be refunds to states or any aspect of it, understands fully the business and accrues the appropriate amounts on ongoing ba
componenttext: I said [indiscernible] and add to it, if you wish, but I view that as an accounting issue. And I think our team here has, whether it be refunds to states or any aspect of it, understands fully the business and accrues the appropriate amounts on ongoing basis. And that's what the board and myself expect. And so those kind of surprises are few and far between for us.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I agree. That product has performed very steadily for us and well over the last 2 years, and there was nothing in the fourth quarter that really was a significant adjustment to change anything of any consequence.
componenttext: Yes, I agree. That product has performed very steadily for us and well over the last 2 years, and there was nothing in the fourth quarter that really was a significant adjustment to change anything of any consequence.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dave Windley of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dave Windley of Jefferies.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: A follow-up to that last one. In terms of your comments in the prepared remarks about -- I think you said enrollment in the individual business was in line to maybe slightly better than what your early expectations were. Can you confirm that? And then wha
componenttext: A follow-up to that last one. In terms of your comments in the prepared remarks about -- I think you said enrollment in the individual business was in line to maybe slightly better than what your early expectations were. Can you confirm that? And then what are your expectations for margin performance in the individual business baked into your guidance?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we commented that, one, the growth is in line with what we expected. And you had the initial enrollment and those that actually pay the premium work through it. So that's coming in as we would expect it to. And on margins, we continue to price it,
componenttext: I think we commented that, one, the growth is in line with what we expected. And you had the initial enrollment and those that actually pay the premium work through it. So that's coming in as we would expect it to. And on margins, we continue to price it, and it continues to perform in line fully with our margins. As I said, we have not priced this product, as we don't think it's right to price it with a great deal of dependency on the 3Rs. And hence, we've had a payable in all our states when you look at the -- those aspects from a consolidated basis within the states, and we see no reason why that's going to change. We maintained the same approach. We have the subsidy population. We commented in the script that the profile of the individuals we've enrolled are the same. And so it's a matter of we're into risk business, and it's called managing the risk.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so, Michael, those expectations are 3%? Or what is your level of expectation?
componenttext: And so, Michael, those expectations are 3%? Or what is your level of expectation?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- in the 3%.
componenttext: The -- in the 3%.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up would be just around guidance assumptions...
componenttext: And then my follow-up would be just around guidance assumptions...

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me say, 3.3% to 3.5% to be more accurate.
componenttext: Let me say, 3.3% to 3.5% to be more accurate.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the precision. In terms of comments on flu, are you assuming, in the early part of '16, that you may be making a conservative assumption about flu, "catching up"? And then what are your assumptions for the end of 2016 and flu season in the fo
componenttext: I appreciate the precision. In terms of comments on flu, are you assuming, in the early part of '16, that you may be making a conservative assumption about flu, "catching up"? And then what are your assumptions for the end of 2016 and flu season in the fourth quarter '16?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we see some indications of it ramping up at this point in time. So that's why I said it's too early to say that there's going to be no flu season at all this year. We've seen flu seasons come early. We've seen them come late. I would say on fourth
componenttext: I think we see some indications of it ramping up at this point in time. So that's why I said it's too early to say that there's going to be no flu season at all this year. We've seen flu seasons come early. We've seen them come late. I would say on fourth quarter, and Jeff can confirm this, but we have booked the normal flu range that we do as we did in every quarter. And it's not the high end or the low end, it's what we reasonably expect it to be.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Peter Costa of Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from Peter Costa of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: First off, let me say thanks and congratulations, Bill. You did great job for us and for Centene. And good luck, Jeff, going forward. And that gets me on my question, which is really about reserves for the company and days and claims payable. What do you
componenttext: First off, let me say thanks and congratulations, Bill. You did great job for us and for Centene. And good luck, Jeff, going forward. And that gets me on my question, which is really about reserves for the company and days and claims payable. What do you expect days and claims payable to do this year, given all the moving parts with sort of less new business and Health Net coming on board? What should we be expecting to see in the days claims payable?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jeff. I mean, we -- as far as on a combined basis with Health Net, we haven't given out anything on that as far as Centene is concerned. I think we have a range from the 40 -- low 40s to mid 40s, I would still expect to be in that range. I do
componenttext: Yes, this is Jeff. I mean, we -- as far as on a combined basis with Health Net, we haven't given out anything on that as far as Centene is concerned. I think we have a range from the 40 -- low 40s to mid 40s, I would still expect to be in that range. I don't see anything unusual happening there. I think the biggest thing that impacts that is the how fast we receive claims and the EDI rate that we have, and we have continued to see an increase in the EDI rate. And so over time, you'd expect that to reduce your days and claims payable. But nothing significant that I would expect.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] important I have said probably in many presentations and meetings that we are averaging 98-plus percent, 98.6% payment in 6 to 8 days or less when the dates of claims comes in. We have a 99% accuracy within the payment of those claims. So
componenttext: [indiscernible] important I have said probably in many presentations and meetings that we are averaging 98-plus percent, 98.6% payment in 6 to 8 days or less when the dates of claims comes in. We have a 99% accuracy within the payment of those claims. So you put all those kinds of factors together, it gives you a high degree of confidence in your lag [ph] tables and those factors and the greatest impact, as Jeff highlighted, will be as claims continue to come in faster, that's the variable. And when you have a constant on the other end of it, that says you don't have to measure as many different, and we use a date receive methodology. So if claims start to come in faster or more of them, then we have 2 out of the 3 factors that are constant.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Should we expect any sort of slowdown as you bring on the Health Net systems and then platform onto your servers?
componenttext: Should we expect any sort of slowdown as you bring on the Health Net systems and then platform onto your servers?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me tell you that we have stated that we're going to be very methodical in bringing on -- because we've seen -- too many times when people try to do it quickly, and they throw the switch and the lights dim. We're going to avoid that. We've stated
componenttext: Well, let me tell you that we have stated that we're going to be very methodical in bringing on -- because we've seen -- too many times when people try to do it quickly, and they throw the switch and the lights dim. We're going to avoid that. We've stated that we anticipate it's going to take 2 years to fully integrate all the systems. They were in the middle of a lot of outsourcing, that's all coming back in. They have a lot of people offshore that will be coming back. So there's a lot of different aspects to it. So anticipate a couple of years, and we'll keep you informed on earnings calls how it's going.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, again, the most significant component of time on days and claims payable is how long it takes from the date of service to when we receive the claims, and that's the majority of the time, as Michael mentioned, how fast we actually process those paymen
componenttext: Yes, again, the most significant component of time on days and claims payable is how long it takes from the date of service to when we receive the claims, and that's the majority of the time, as Michael mentioned, how fast we actually process those payments once we receive the claim.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Andy Schenker of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Andy Schenker of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So even in the past, when you provide guidance, you've called out kind of investment and expansion cost. I mean given the new programs and expansions this year, excluding Health Net, maybe how should we think about investment cost in either ideally absolu
componenttext: So even in the past, when you provide guidance, you've called out kind of investment and expansion cost. I mean given the new programs and expansions this year, excluding Health Net, maybe how should we think about investment cost in either ideally absolute terms or at least relative to 2015, and how should we think about that trend going forward?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jeff. I mean we haven't -- we're in this spot here where we are kind of waiting for the Health Net transaction to close here. So we haven't gotten into those details. I think once the transaction closes, we'll provide all of the normal, I wou
componenttext: Yes, this is Jeff. I mean we haven't -- we're in this spot here where we are kind of waiting for the Health Net transaction to close here. So we haven't gotten into those details. I think once the transaction closes, we'll provide all of the normal, I would say, guidance information including tax rate, shares outstanding, start-up costs, et cetera, et cetera. But right now, we're just in a position where, as you've seen, we went from February to March 1. We're just in a position where we really have to wait until closing.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Switching gears then. So duals, obviously, never been meaningful for Centene and definitely been a slightly disappointing program here. But given concerns around the program, are you seeing any changes from the states around renewed interest in maybe inde
componenttext: Switching gears then. So duals, obviously, never been meaningful for Centene and definitely been a slightly disappointing program here. But given concerns around the program, are you seeing any changes from the states around renewed interest in maybe independent or separate long-term support services programs? Are you seeing any potential growth in that RFP pipeline? Can you talk about LTSS separate from duals?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] that I've had some discussion with states on these duals, and some of the needs they've to do to reduce the dis-enrollment that one season that population. We're doing a little better on Ohio. I think last time I looked, it was around 30%
componenttext: [indiscernible] that I've had some discussion with states on these duals, and some of the needs they've to do to reduce the dis-enrollment that one season that population. We're doing a little better on Ohio. I think last time I looked, it was around 30% versus the 50% that we're seeing in some other states, but I think the states recognize it. And It's just a matter of what they have on their plate and their willingness to do that.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just on the second part of that, Andy. We have seen the momentum really is around states looking at the LTSS programs for managed long-term care as kind of an extension, if you will, of the dual demo program. So you're not seeing a lot of new dual de
componenttext: Yes, just on the second part of that, Andy. We have seen the momentum really is around states looking at the LTSS programs for managed long-term care as kind of an extension, if you will, of the dual demo program. So you're not seeing a lot of new dual demo programs coming out, but you're seeing meaningful amount of momentum on managed long-term care contracts either embedded within kind of existing states or RFPs, they would be specific for that sort of services.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Steven Halper of FBR.
componenttext: Our next question is from Steven Halper of FBR.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any update on the disk drive issue?
componenttext: Any update on the disk drive issue?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me -- we -- thank you for calling the disk drive issue. Because it's really a data issue in our case. There was no intrusion, there was no hacking. Appreciate the way you articulated it, it was very important. We continue down the process, we
componenttext: Yes, so let me -- we -- thank you for calling the disk drive issue. Because it's really a data issue in our case. There was no intrusion, there was no hacking. Appreciate the way you articulated it, it was very important. We continue down the process, we continue to look at it. We continue to apply an abundance of conservatism and transparency to it. Clearly, to this point, we have seen no hint or any indication of any inappropriate use of the data. And we are continuing the search and looking to see -- when we have 26,000 discs. And you're looking for 6, that's the proverbial needle in the haystack. And we're doing that methodically, again just to double check it. So there's no update beyond that. But as I said, we're following through. We're notifying everybody. And importantly, Steven, this data was an incredibly raw form. We're using it to line up the state's laboratory and other data. So it's not a very usable state. You really have to have a lot of our systems to get to it. But once again, as soon as we see something that could be an issue, our policy is to get it out there.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to confirm, from your understanding, there's been no inappropriate use of any of the data that would've been on these drives?
componenttext: Just to confirm, from your understanding, there's been no inappropriate use of any of the data that would've been on these drives?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Absolutely no hint even of inappropriateness.
componenttext: No. Absolutely no hint even of inappropriateness.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Ralph Giacobbe of Citi.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Just wanted to go back to the exchanges real quick. Certainly, I understand that, I guess, the enrollment numbers are coming in line with your expectation. Can you give us what those numbers are in terms of where you're at right now through open enrollment? And then second piece is just the renewal percentage, like so of the exchange book last year. Can you give us a sense of what percentage of lives renewed?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
