componenttext: My memory is that [indiscernible] enrollment was around 600,000, but that doesn't include those that have paid, and there is still some crunching of those numbers, so we expected probably be 75% or something of what has shown in indication. As always it is an early indication. And then, like the old saying, until you pay, you don't have the coverage.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Did you say 600? So 146 up to 600,000? And then you think maybe 75% stack?
componenttext: Did you say 600? So 146 up to 600,000? And then you think maybe 75% stack?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Maybe an [indiscernible] of what, 400 or so? 500 [indiscernible].
componenttext: No. Maybe an [indiscernible] of what, 400 or so? 500 [indiscernible].

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, again, that's about the number for the peak point enrollment. I think it's important to note that the enrollment peaks and then continues to reduce down through the year. We anticipate that, experience that. So your 146 is the low point of the year i
componenttext: Yes, again, that's about the number for the peak point enrollment. I think it's important to note that the enrollment peaks and then continues to reduce down through the year. We anticipate that, experience that. So your 146 is the low point of the year in terms of comparison in terms of that.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jesse. I'll just add to that, that Michael made some of these comments in his prepared remarks. This -- the growth that we're seeing is in the states where we have had longstanding participation in the marketplace. We're known in those produc
componenttext: Yes, this is Jesse. I'll just add to that, that Michael made some of these comments in his prepared remarks. This -- the growth that we're seeing is in the states where we have had longstanding participation in the marketplace. We're known in those products, and we've seen the demographics, consistent approach that we've taken in terms of discipline in our networks and pricing, et cetera, and the demographics for those peak membership that Michael referenced is wholesale in line with what we have seen over the past 2 years.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then the 146 from last year, do you have the renewal percent like the most of those renew? Is the renewal rate high?
componenttext: Okay, and then the 146 from last year, do you have the renewal percent like the most of those renew? Is the renewal rate high?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The renewal rate is very high. So we did see most of our people, reasonable number renew like we expected.
componenttext: The renewal rate is very high. So we did see most of our people, reasonable number renew like we expected.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one more. Can you maybe help frame the opportunity from Louisiana expanding Medicaid? I think you mentioned it, it isn't in guidance. So just wondering sort of the opportunity there, maybe me remind us of cost trend and MLR within the states
componenttext: And then just one more. Can you maybe help frame the opportunity from Louisiana expanding Medicaid? I think you mentioned it, it isn't in guidance. So just wondering sort of the opportunity there, maybe me remind us of cost trend and MLR within the states that already have expanded Medicaid? I think in the past you've suggested that MLR actually runs lower than average within a Medicaid expansion population. Should we expect the same from Louisiana?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible we want to take that?
componenttext: [indiscernible we want to take that?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: MLRs are slightly lower for the Medicaid expansion population than our overall average MLR given the lower -- slightly lower acuity of the population, so that would be kind of in line with our expectations. And then the total program size is about expecte
componenttext: MLRs are slightly lower for the Medicaid expansion population than our overall average MLR given the lower -- slightly lower acuity of the population, so that would be kind of in line with our expectations. And then the total program size is about expected to be about 250,000 members. That could grow over time, and there are 5 managed care organization in Louisiana. So those are the rough dimensions for the opportunity.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ana Gupte of Leerink Partners.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ana Gupte of Leerink Partners.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first question is on the guidance. You might have said a little bit of this at Investor Day, but you've since won a few contracts, just on a stand-alone basis, what are you modeling in the guidance for your or for Centene's loss ratio consolidated acr
componenttext: The first question is on the guidance. You might have said a little bit of this at Investor Day, but you've since won a few contracts, just on a stand-alone basis, what are you modeling in the guidance for your or for Centene's loss ratio consolidated across your [indiscernible] growth expansion growth and any rate changes? And then within Centene itself, the new versus existing businesses and integrating your acquisition?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jeff. You're a little hard to hear there, but I think as I commented at our Investor Day, we're not going to give stand-alone guidance for Centene. So we'll have to get into that on a combined basis once the transaction closes.
componenttext: Yes, this is Jeff. You're a little hard to hear there, but I think as I commented at our Investor Day, we're not going to give stand-alone guidance for Centene. So we'll have to get into that on a combined basis once the transaction closes.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Specifically then, I guess, I don't get the overall number or directional trend. When you said start-up costs, so you modeling in like a PDR-type thing for this new correctional care contract in Nebraska and all from '16 losses into your guidance? So you
componenttext: Specifically then, I guess, I don't get the overall number or directional trend. When you said start-up costs, so you modeling in like a PDR-type thing for this new correctional care contract in Nebraska and all from '16 losses into your guidance? So you don't really see that as an accounting practice that you will adopt?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't think PDR's in that business, we tend to avoid going into businesses where there is a PDR before you see your first member.
componenttext: We don't think PDR's in that business, we tend to avoid going into businesses where there is a PDR before you see your first member.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add is that when we prepare our budgets and operating plans, we assume we're going to win business and have new plans coming in every year. So when we said, for example, in the fourth quarter, we've included the start-up cost for so
componenttext: The only thing I would add is that when we prepare our budgets and operating plans, we assume we're going to win business and have new plans coming in every year. So when we said, for example, in the fourth quarter, we've included the start-up cost for something like Nebraska, that's because we're always anticipating a certain level of those business expansion costs.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so no PDR, but expansion cost. And then finally, just looking at some of the news flow, which may just be all headline risk, but with what's going on in Kentucky with the new governor in Iowa with a Democratic Senate and all, as I think about any po
componenttext: Okay, so no PDR, but expansion cost. And then finally, just looking at some of the news flow, which may just be all headline risk, but with what's going on in Kentucky with the new governor in Iowa with a Democratic Senate and all, as I think about any potential downside risk on rates in expansion states, California for Health Net and anything else you're doing where might you see any [indiscernible].

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have really great actuaries. We will not sign a contract where we don't think it's adequate rates and it's just that simple. We look at it. We recognize that it may not be profitable from day 1, but we have to have clear visibility. And I can tell you,
componenttext: We have really great actuaries. We will not sign a contract where we don't think it's adequate rates and it's just that simple. We look at it. We recognize that it may not be profitable from day 1, but we have to have clear visibility. And I can tell you, it is policy to not go into a state if we think we're going to do a PDR before we have our first member. I'm going to drop it at that point [indiscernible].

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Matthew Borsch of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Matthew Borsch of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry if you covered this already, but can you just comment on your outlook for the California duals program? I realize that's not under your umbrella yet, but it will be soon. And it's been -- the programs been held up politically. I'm just wondering wha
componenttext: Sorry if you covered this already, but can you just comment on your outlook for the California duals program? I realize that's not under your umbrella yet, but it will be soon. And it's been -- the programs been held up politically. I'm just wondering what type of opportunity you see there and how you think it might unfold?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean what's important -- we -- and I've said this multiple times, in no way, at any time, for the past [indiscernible] demonstration have we looked to the dual product for any of our growth. We've recognized that it would be a very slow, difficult proce
componenttext: I mean what's important -- we -- and I've said this multiple times, in no way, at any time, for the past [indiscernible] demonstration have we looked to the dual product for any of our growth. We've recognized that it would be a very slow, difficult process the way we structured, with the opt-outs, et cetera. And for that reason, we've said from the beginning that it's just not something that we put a lot behind with. We're doing enough. And I think we've said at the Investor Day, we get to a high in total between the 2 companies to 50,000 or something. We're doing enough to demonstrate that we really know how to do it and do it well. So that when -- and we're working with the state issues that, in fact, the opt-out, so that when and if they decide to do something about it, we're in a strong position. And beyond that, I have no great expectations. And it's not going to make or break any state or any year for us.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just philosophically, do you think that dual program can work on an opt-out basis? Or do you think it'll going have to get to a point where you put one program in as opposed to running 2 concurrently?
componenttext: Just philosophically, do you think that dual program can work on an opt-out basis? Or do you think it'll going have to get to a point where you put one program in as opposed to running 2 concurrently?

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're going to have to have the problematic -- programmatic changes to minimize the opt outs, always some, but you can't have 50% opt-out and have any continuity of care. So that has to change.
componenttext: I think you're going to have to have the problematic -- programmatic changes to minimize the opt outs, always some, but you can't have 50% opt-out and have any continuity of care. So that has to change.

headline: Centene Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: This concludes our question-and-answer session. I'd like to turn the conference back over to Michael Neidorff for any closing remarks.

componenttext: Thank you. I want to thank you all for your interest, comments, and we look forward to another very strong year. And we're off, and Jeff will be giving the same kind reports that Bill has. So thank you everybody. Have a good day.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Centene Corp. First Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ed Kroll, Senior Vice President of Fin
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Centene Corp. First Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Ed Kroll, Senior Vice President of Finance, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Emily, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2016 first quarter earnings release conference call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Jeff Schwaneke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Thank you, Emily, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2016 first quarter earnings release conference call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Jeff Schwaneke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Centene, will host this morning's call. The call should last approximately 45 minutes and may also be accessed through our website at centene.com at the Investor Relations section. A replay will be available shortly after the call's completion, also at centene.com, or by dialing (877) 344-7529 in the U.S. and Canada or in other countries by dialing (412) 317-0088. The playback code for both dial-ins is 10083202. 
Any remarks that Centene may make about future expectations, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provision under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by these forward-looking statements as a result of various important factors, including those discussed in Centene's most recently filed Form 10-Q filed today, April 26, 2016; Form 10-K, which was filed February 22, 2016; and other public SEC filings. Centene anticipates that subsequent events and developments will cause its estimates to change. While the company may elect to update these forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, Michael Neidorff. Michael?

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. We are very pleased to have closed the Health Net acquisition within the first quarter, as projected. I would like to begin with a few comments
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. We are very pleased to have closed the Health Net acquisition within the first quarter, as projected. 
I would like to begin with a few comments on why the addition of Health Net is transformational. In closing the acquisition, Centene has achieved the following: further critical mass, including additional product diversification within the government-sponsored health care space. We are a $40 billion-plus company. We are the largest Medicaid managed care organization in the country serving 6.7 million Medicaid members at March 31. We are the leader in 3 of the largest Medicaid states: California, Texas and Florida. We are the largest provider of managed long-term support services, one of the fastest-growing segments of the market. We have a 4-star Medicare Advantage product that can be exported to additional markets, and we provide services under contracts with the U.S. Department of Defense and Veterans Affairs. This greater scale enhances the positive view of Centene nationally as well as by state and local governments. It strengthens our ability to help shape sound public health care policy. In addition, it enhances our purchasing power and is beneficial from a balance sheet perspective. 
Centene is now clearly a large-cap company in stock. We recently joined the S&P 500 Index. This is important to us as this index is regarded as the best single gauge of large-cap U.S. equities. Additionally, we will widen our potential investor base and lead to increase liquidity of our stock. Lastly, this acquisition enhances and solidifies the sustainability of Centene's long-term growth rate. 
I would now like to comment on the timing of the approval process and provide an update on integration. While the regulatory process in California was lengthier than expected, it was fair and the undertakings contained no surprises. We will be making investments in certain state-affiliated investment-grade vehicles as well as in a local service center. The placement of a service center in California is consistent with Centene's local approach. We will work with the state to find a suitable location in an economically disadvantaged area where job creation is needed. The investments and charitable contributions associated with these undertakings have been included in our guidance and will be made over a multiple-year period. The planning portion of the integration process was largely completed prior to closing. Our integration team did extensive work to ensure a smooth and seamless combination. We were able to hit the ground running the day of the close, and integration is preceding as expected. 
Before I provide first quarter highlights, I want to remind you that our first quarter results included only 8 days of Health Net's financials as the transaction closed on March 24. Our prior guidance had assumed a March 1 close date. We have updated our 2016 guidance to reflect the later close. This is a timing issue only, and we remain confident that our previously anticipated run rate earnings remain on track. Additionally, we have adjusted our reporting to reflect the increased scale of the business and our new product mix. We believe this provides meaningful information to investors, and it will continue to evolve as we complete the Health Net integration. 
Turning to the first quarter financials. We are pleased with the results of the first quarter. There were many moving parts when combining the 2 companies, including onetime charges and prorating for [indiscernible] 
Total revenues increased 36% year-over-year to $7 billion. Membership at quarter-end was 11.5 million, representing an increase of 7.1 million members or 162% over the first quarter of 2015. The HBR improved 110 basis points year-over-year to 88.7%. The first quarter pretax margin, excluding acquisition-related cost, improved 30 basis points year-over-year to 3%. We reported adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.74. This compares to $0.55 in the first quarter of 2015. Jeff will provide further financial details, including the updated 2016 guidance, in his prepared remarks. 
A quick note on flu. We saw an uptick in flu during the first quarter. The flu appears to have peaked in March, and overall costs were in line with our expectations. Overall, we continue to see as well as anticipate stable medical cost trends. 
Next, market and product updates. First, we will discuss recent Medicaid activity. 
Washington State. In April, Centene commenced operations under the Apple Foster Care contract in Washington as the sole provider for this program. The contract is performing in line with expectations, and we anticipate serving over 20,000 across the state. With the addition of this contract, Centene will serve approximately 100,000 Foster Care beneficiaries across all of our markets. 
Nebraska. Also on April, Centene executed a contract with Nebraska as 1 of 3 managed care organizations to administer the state's new Heritage Health program, which covers 230 Medicaid CHIP and ABD enrollees. This contract is expected to commence in the first quarter of 2017. 
Texas. We expect to start CHIP contract in Texas to commence in the latter part of 2016. Centene is the only managed care organization in Texas to participate in all of the state's Medicaid and Medicaid-related product lines. 
Next, Medicaid expansion. At March 31, we served approximately 985,000 Medicaid expansion members in 9 states. This represents an increase of more than 650,000 [ph] recipients over the first quarter of 2015. This growth was primarily driven by the additional Health Net Medicaid expansion [indiscernible] In January, the Governor of Louisiana signed an Executive Order to expand Medicaid coverage under the ACA. This is expected to be begin in July and is now included in our updated 2016 guidance. 
Now Medicare and duals. At March 31, we served over 303,000 Medicare and dual beneficiaries. We continue to expect to launch additional Medicare Advantage brands in 4 Centene states in 2017. The new Medicare Advantage brands will be launched under our 4-Star Banner, which will give us the benefit of incremental premium revenues. 
Next, Health Insurance Marketplace. Centene's exchange experience continues to be favorable, and we are achieving margins at the higher end of our targeted range. Our market pre-strategy has been and continues to be focused on targeted low-income, subsidized individuals, many of whom were previously Medicaid-eligible. We designed our exchange solution to be able to leverage our Medicaid platform, including provider networks. In the majority of our markets, we have both Medicaid and market-based product offerings. We coined the term churn to reference those members who can retain coverage through a high-quality, affordable Centene product in either Medicaid or the exchange. In the first quarter, over 90% of our exchange members were subsidy-eligible. This is consistent with 2014 and 2015. 
Centene has maintained a disciplined approach to pricing from day 1. In fact, we are in a net payable position for the 3Rs program. At March 31, we served over 680,000 [ph] exchange members across 15 states. At year-end, we expect over 550,000 exchange beneficiaries due to the normal attrition. 
Now Centurion. Our correctional health business continues to successfully expand. At March 31, we served 59,000 correctional members, represent year-over-year growth of 38%. In April, Centurion replaced its existing 1-year contract in Mississippi with a new 3-year contract, which is expected to commence in July. Also in April, we began providing correctional health services in 3 regions in Florida. This marks Centurion's sixth [ph] state population. 
Finally, commercial. We ended the first quarter with over 830,000 commercial members. We are fully committed to the success of the existing business, especially in California. However, we have no plans at this time to expand into additional states. 
Shifting gears to our rate output. For Medicaid, we continue to expect the 2016 composite rate adjustment of between 0 and 1%, consistent with the past 2 [ph] years. We have known rates for our Medicaid business representing approximately 65% of the projected 2016 member bonds. For Medicare Advantage, final 2017 rates were announced on April 4. These were in line with our expectations of an approximate 1%. 
In conclusion, with first quarter results, we're off to a good start in 2016. We expect this momentum to continue throughout the year. We are on track with our integration of Health Net. Our synergy targets remain $75 million for the first 12 months following the close and $150 million in the second 12 months following the close. While we remain committed to long-term margin expansion, we continue to expect the 2016 pretax margins to remain relatively flat compared to 2015 as we focus on integration. Our growth pipeline is bigger than ever with the additional products and capabilities in health care. We are optimistic about the future and our ability to expand Centene's leadership position in government-sponsored health care. 
As a reminder, our Investor Day is on June 17 in New York City. We look forward to seeing you then. We thank you for your continued interest in Centene. 
Jeff will now provide further details on our first quarter financial results. Jeff?

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good morning. This morning, I will begin with highlighting the results for the first quarter of 2016 and will provide an update on our 2016 full year guidance, including the acquisition of Health Net. First, I would like to highl
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good morning. This morning, I will begin with highlighting the results for the first quarter of 2016 and will provide an update on our 2016 full year guidance, including the acquisition of Health Net. 
First, I would like to highlight the effect of the Health Net transaction in the first quarter 2016 results. As previously announced, we completed the acquisition of Health Net on March 24, 2016, for a purchase price of $6 billion, including the assumption of debt. In connection with the completion of the acquisition, we incurred approximately $189 million or $0.83 per diluted share of transaction cost, which includes accelerated stock compensation service, investment banking fees, legal cost and the pertinent value of the $65 million charitable donation under agreements with the U.S. regulatory agencies. Additionally, we had included $8 million [ph] [indiscernible] in our first quarter of 2016 results. The 8 days of activity represents approximately $350 million of revenue and had a minimal effect on our HBR, G&A ratio and adjusted diluted earnings per share. 
Now onto the first quarter highlights. For the first quarter, membership of 11.5 million members, an increase of 162% for 2 years [ph] driven by the Health Net acquisition. Total revenues for the first quarter [ph] of $7 billion, [ph] an increase of 36% over Q1 in 2015. [indiscernible] per share for the first quarter of 2016 compares with [indiscernible] and adjusted diluted earnings per share is $0.74, [indiscernible] Health Net acquisition costs and intangible amortization, compared to $0.55 on an adjusted basis last year. 
In more detail, total revenues grew by $1.8 billion in the first quarter, primarily as a result of expansions [indiscernible] in many of our states for 2015, growth of the Health Insurance Marketplace business and 8 days of revenue from the Health Net acquisition. Our health benefits ratio was 88.7% in the first quarter this year compared to 89.8% in last year's first quarter or 88% [ph] for the fourth quarter. The 110 basis points decrease year-over-year was also an improvement in the overall HBR for [indiscernible] particularly long-term care and growth in the Health Insurance Marketplace membership, which continues to perform well. 
Sequentially, the 70 [ph] basis point increase from the fourth quarter [indiscernible] for the first quarter of 2016. For the first quarter, 18% premium and service revenues [indiscernible] the new business compared to 23% from the first quarter of 2015. The existing business metrics in the quarter [indiscernible] Health Net [indiscernible] acquisition, and we expect the percentage of revenue of new business to decrease to a single-digit percentage by the end of the year due to the larger revenue base and the denominator. The health benefits ratio for new business were 96 -- 90.6% and 88.3% for existing business and the purchase order. 
The Health Insurance Marketplace product continues to perform well in 2016 with over 680,000 members [ph] at March 31. With the addition of Health Net, we continue to be in a net [indiscernible] position for the risk corridor and risk adjustment components of the 3Rs. As part of our initial good valuation procedures associated with the acquisition, we have reduced the [indiscernible] of the Health Net this quarter [indiscernible  Additionally, consistent with our historical accounting practice and guidance, we will not put any risk corridors [indiscernible] 2016 figures. Our general and administrative expense ratio was 11.3% in the first quarter this year or 8.3% without the cost associated with the Health Net acquisition compared to 8.3% last year and 8.7% in the fourth quarter, also excluding Health Net acquisition costs. The decrease from the fourth quarter of 2015 reflects the reduction in cost related to [indiscernible] with the Health Insurance Marketplace [indiscernible  
During the first quarter, we incurred $0.02 [ph] per diluted share of business expansion cost compared to $0.06 [ph] for the year. Investment and other income was $15 billion [ph] in the first quarter compared with $9 million last year and $8 million in the fourth quarter. Interest expense was $33 million for the first quarter of 2016 compared to $10 million for the first quarter last year and $11 million for the fourth quarter last year. The increase is due to the issuance of $2.4 billion of senior notes on February 11, 2016, [indiscernible] integration for the Health Net acquisition. Consistent with what we have been done in the past, [indiscernible] our balance sheet exposure to short-term interest rates, on March 30, 2016, we introduced the interest rate swap agreements for a notional amount of $1.6 million [ph] [indiscernible] substantial portion of senior notes to the floating rate of interest at [indiscernible] LIBOR plus 4.36% [ph] [indiscernible] stock expense of $17 million on a pretax income of $2 million for the first quarter of 2016 due to the non-deductibility of certain Health Net acquisition costs as well as [indiscernible] in the health insurance. GAAP diluted earnings per share from continuing operations for the first quarter was $0.13. [ph] Adjusted diluted earnings per share for the first quarter was exactly $0.04. Adjusted diluted earnings per share includes $0.83 [ph] associated with the Health Net acquisition costs and $0.04 associated with the [indiscernible] 
Cash and investments totaled almost $8 billion at quarter-end, including $139 million held by unregulated subsidiaries. We estimate our NAIC risk-based capital percentage to be in excess of 350% [ph] [indiscernible] Debt on March 31 was $4.3 billion, including $515 million of borrowings on our revolver. Our debt-to-capital ratio, excluding 12.3%, [ph] excluding our [indiscernible] compared to 34.7% in the fourth quarter 2015. 
Our medical claim liability totaled $3.9 billion in March 31, representing 42 days in claims payable normalizing for Health Net acquisition. During the first quarter, we made provisional estimates for the fair value of the medical claims liability associated with Health Net. We have not completed our fair valuation exercise, and we announced [indiscernible] change. Any change in the provisional estimates would be recorded as an adjustment to the opening balance sheet and will have no effect on net earnings. Cash flow from operations is $195 million [ph] in first quarter compared to $35 million [ph] in the first quarter of 2015. Additionally, you will note that we have adjusted our reporting this quarter to reflect the sale of the business for new product. We believe this provides meaningful information to investors and will continue to involve with the integration to the company. 
This concludes my remarks for the first quarter results. Now I would like to provide you update on our full year guidance. We have adjusted our 2016 guidance to reflect the large [indiscernible] in the Health Net acquisition. We have lowered the top and bottom end of the revenue guidance by $1 billion, lowered both end to our adjusted diluted earnings per share guidance of $0.05 [ph] to reflect the transaction closing shifting to March 1 to 24. Changing closing date does not have an impact on our run rate revenues or earnings. We now expect total revenues to be between $39 billion [ph] and $39.8 billion [ph] which represents an increase of approximately 73% [ph] of the midpoint of our guidance as compared to 2015. Our 2016 guidance for health benefits ratio is 87% to 87.5%, a decrease from 2015 of approximately 160 [ph] basis points at the midpoint of the guidance. 
Production in HBR, year-over-year, is due to the addition of Health Net, which operates in the lower HBR due to the higher mix conversion and growth in the health [indiscernible] marketplace, which operates with lower HBR and higher G&A ratio. 
General and administrative expense ratio is expected to be between 9.4% to 9.9% in 2016. On an adjusted basis, and excluding acquisition costs, the G&A ratio is expected to increase by 75 basis points between years to 9% to 9.5%. This increase is due to the addition of Health Net, which operates at a higher [indiscernible] expense ratio due to the mix of business, offset by additional leverage associated with revenue deals [indiscernible 
Other revenue and expense, interest income is forecasted to be between $90 million and $100 million, and interest expense is estimated to be between $180 million to $190 million. We estimate business expansion cost of $0.25 [ph] and $0.30 [ph] [indiscernible] We estimate that our effective income tax rate for 2016, excluding noncontrolling interest, will be 55% to 57%, relatively high effective tax rate [indiscernible] impact of nondeductible agreement with the health insurer fee and non-deductibility of certain acquisition costs associated with the Health Net acquisition. In 2016, we anticipate the health insurer fee increases to approximately $450 million. We estimate our diluted shares outstanding to be between 162.5 to 163.5 million shares. 2016, we expect GAAP diluted earnings per share to between $2.45 to $2.80, adjusted diluted earnings per share to be between $4 and $4.35. These amounts include Health Net and related synergies for 9 months [ph] and 8 days in 2016. Adjusted diluted earnings per share excludes 2 items: first, the amortization of intangible assets [indiscernible] acquisitions, and we estimate to be between $0.50 and $0.55 per share; and two, Health Net acquisition-related expenses, which we estimate to be between $1 and $1.05 per diluted share. Additionally, our guidance assumes no receivable for the programs and payable [indiscernible] for 2016. 
We believe the guidance we would have provided today are generally [indiscernible] financial information [indiscernible] statement adjusted to include only 9 months and 8 days of Health Net activity due to the March 23 [ph] closing. We continue to expect $75 million of net synergies in the next 12 months, following closing of the transaction. We estimate our operating cash flow to be between 1.5 to 2x net earnings. 
That concludes my remarks. And operator, you may now open the lines for questions.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- there are couple of elements. One, we do not participate in any processes or auctions, whatever you call it, today. So to the extent that is, we're out of that. Two, the controlling issue, particularly in the Medicare-related business, will be
componenttext: I think -- there are couple of elements. One, we do not participate in any processes or auctions, whatever you call it, today. So to the extent that is, we're out of that. Two, the controlling issue, particularly in the Medicare-related business, will be the network. If they have a network that's not in our sweet spot, which is at the lower social economic level, then we won't have any interest in it. So we have so much organic opportunity. I mean our pipeline is very robust, and I'm not -- we're not really of mind that we need that to meet our growth targets. If it's there and it makes sense, we do it.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- United -- and I have a lot of respect for and his people and what they do and their approach to things. But they're doing a different market than what we are from what I can see. There was a lot of individual, ACS and they're at the highe
componenttext: Well, I think -- United -- and I have a lot of respect for and his people and what they do and their approach to things. But they're doing a different market than what we are from what I can see. There was a lot of individual, ACS and they're at the higher end in the platinum and the gold. To the extent that they have a membership that would fit within ours -- our model, sure we take them on, but I'm not anticipating any large gain from that either just because of the differences.

componenttext: Well, obviously, we believe it's going well. And once again, I've -- in many conferences, I've commented that it's a $700 billion category, of which 65% is at 400% of the federal poverty level and lower. And that's our sweet spot. And that's where our networks are now. And so to the extent that's why when people ask about some things that others may have to give up, we question the network that they serve. But we think we have in place a network of that population prefers to use, and we're just expanded, very candidly. When you're in Medicare, you have more orthopedic surgeons and other things that affect more of the elderly population. And so we're throwing that out, as appropriate, and we have a strong team doing it.

componenttext: Yes. This is Jeff. I mean, I think the way we always look at leap year is just an extra day of medical costs when we do our forecasting, when we put our budget together. componenttext: I think, forgive me, if we start up, we would [indiscernible] one side [indiscernible] that. So there's no one thing that we can call out. Jeff [indiscernible] that he wishes. And only thing that will call out that is a positive or negative. But as I've talked about historically, we have a size and a scale that -- we're 24, 25 states, growing the number. 280 [ph] -- 260 [ph] contracts within those states. Any given time, we'll have one contract in the state that's an issue, and we will have a couple that that are offsetting it. So it's the security and stability of diversification. And so that's why that's what's makes it so hard to call out any one particular thing because I'd like to think there's no one issue that can have a total deleterious effect on the whole company. I hope that helps.

componenttext: To date, there's only been symptomatic flu cases of Zika. There's not really been a case of the cash profit consequences except for one in Hawaii. We are -- we're tracking that. The projections of Zika are really unpredictable based on Latin American experience, but we are optimistic that the government's position or chief position that the burden -- of the disease burden on United States should be very small. It's probably very accurate and the cost of testing or visit should be relatively minimal.

componenttext: I think the infrastructure, of course, is in place, and the advantage we have is that we have very strong decentralized plants that the -- if you were to [indiscernible] local CEOs and teams now down to indigenous guys, a product in their market, we don't just take something from California and parachute it in right now. So there's an aspect of it. I think the thing that we're cognizant of in thinking about is that there's a different acquisition costs in Medicare products. It's something some of us have been historically understand. So it would take a -- it will not take a gigantic significant amount of critical mass to start to see it provide some margin to us. But I'd expect in the first few quarters to have some expense that -- well, not necessarily be fully offset by the revenue [indiscernible] that something will get more into at year-end when we have the specifics and give guidance on those '17, as we always do.

componenttext: Well, I think will be a competition, depending on the participant services. Going -- I think, as I said earlier, if I'd -- it would have more orthopedic surgeons type. So that's all driven by that amount. I think the dollar amount of the rebate is somewhere north of $400 million on rebates for the Medicaid expansion business for Health Net in California.

componenttext: No. I would -- more saying that risk adjusters will be pulled -- though you are profitable and maybe they are not, it's a pooled program, as I understand. So is there in worse acuity, even though you may get better acuity, might your payable be meaningfully higher than it is in '16? Because if they raised prices a lot, healthier people could fall off. And so the risks gets worse, if you will. So was wondering what happens there.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we tried -- we price for the estimated risk pool in the state, and we try to be careful about looking at the changes that are going to happen from one year to the next with respect to that risk pool, and I think we've had a pretty good track
componenttext: Well, I think we tried -- we price for the estimated risk pool in the state, and we try to be careful about looking at the changes that are going to happen from one year to the next with respect to that risk pool, and I think we've had a pretty good track record with respect to being able to do that to this point. I think that if they raise their prices, some of the healthier members, we would hope would accrue to us with respect to that. And again, we try to carefully look at the dynamics of how that would affect the actual risk adjustment amount that we might have to reflect related to our acuity, including how the risk adjuster tool works in each state. And I think that we've reflected what we think is an accurate view of the dynamics for 2017. Just back to another comment you mentioned that the reinsurance program is going away in 2017, and that is certainly something that will need to be reflected in our pricing in 2017 and something that we're very mindful of.

componenttext: Yes, this is Rone Baldwin. In aggregate, the exchange business at Centene -- excuse me, at Health Net, has been profitable. Good morning, and welcome to the Centene Corp. First Quarter 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Ed Kroll, Senior Vice President of Finance, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Emily, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2016 first quarter earnings release conference call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Jeff Schwaneke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Thank you, Emily, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2016 first quarter earnings release conference call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Jeff Schwaneke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Centene, will host this morning's call. The call should last approximately 45 minutes and may also be accessed through our website at centene.com at the Investor Relations section. A replay will be available shortly after the call's completion, also at centene.com, or by dialing (877) 344-7529 in the U.S. and Canada or in other countries by dialing (412) 317-0088. The playback code for both dial-ins is 10083202. 
Any remarks that Centene may make about future expectations, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provision under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by these forward-looking statements as a result of various important factors, including those discussed in Centene's most recently filed Form 10-Q filed today, April 26, 2016; Form 10-K, which was filed February 22, 2016; and other public SEC filings. Centene anticipates that subsequent events and developments will cause its estimates to change. While the company may elect to update these forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, Michael Neidorff. Michael?

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. We are very pleased to have closed the Health Net acquisition within the first quarter, as projected. I would like to begin with a few comments
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. We are very pleased to have closed the Health Net acquisition within the first quarter, as projected. 
I would like to begin with a few comments on why the addition of Health Net is transformational. In closing the acquisition, Centene has achieved the following: further critical mass, including additional product diversification within the government-sponsored health care space. We are a $40 billion-plus company. We are the largest Medicaid managed care organization in the country serving 6.7 million Medicaid members at March 31. We are the leader in 3 of the largest Medicaid states: California, Texas and Florida. We are the largest provider of managed long-term support services, one of the fastest-growing segments of the market. We have a 4-star Medicare Advantage product that can be exported to additional markets, and we provide services under contracts with the U.S. Department of Defense and Veterans Affairs. This greater scale enhances the positive view of Centene nationally as well as by state and local governments. It strengthens our ability to help shape sound public health care policy. In addition, it enhances our purchasing power and is beneficial from a balance sheet perspective. 
Centene is now clearly a large-cap company, in stock. We recently joined the S&P 500 Index. This is important to us as this index is regarded as the best single gauge of large-cap U.S. equities. Additionally, it will widen our potential investor base and lead to increased liquidity of our stock. Lastly, this acquisition enhances and solidifies the sustainability of Centene's long-term growth rate. 
I would now like to comment on the timing of the approval process and provide an update on integration. While the regulatory process in California was lengthier than expected, it was fair and the undertakings contained no surprises. We will be making investments in certain state-affiliated investment-grade vehicles as well as in a local service center. The placement of a service center in California is consistent with Centene's local approach. We will work with the state to find a suitable location in an economically disadvantaged area where job creation is needed. The investments and charitable contributions associated with these undertakings have been included in our guidance and will be made over a multiple-year period. The planning portion of the integration process was largely completed prior to closing. Our integration team did extensive work to ensure a smooth and seamless combination. We were able to hit the ground running the day of the close, and the integration is proceeding as expected. 
Before I provide first quarter highlights, I want to remind you that our first quarter results included only 8 days of Health Net's financials as the transaction closed on March 24. Our prior guidance had assumed a March 1 close date. We have updated our 2016 guidance to reflect the later close. This is a timing issue only, and we remain confident that our previously anticipated run rate earnings remain on track. Additionally, we have adjusted our reporting to reflect the increased scale of the business and our new product mix. We believe this provides meaningful information to investors, and it will continue to evolve as we complete the Health Net integration. 
Turning to the first quarter financials. We are pleased with the results of the first quarter. There were many moving parts when combining the 2 companies, including onetime charges and prorating for [indiscernible].
Total revenues increased 36% year-over-year to $7 billion. Membership at quarter-end was 11.5 million, representing an increase of 7.1 million members or 162% over the first quarter of 2015. The HBR improved 110 basis points year-over-year to 88.7%. The first quarter pretax margin, excluding acquisition-related cost, improved 30 basis points year-over-year to 3%. We reported adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.74. This compares to $0.55 in the first quarter of 2015. Jeff will provide further financial details, including the updated 2016 guidance, in his prepared remarks. 
A quick note on flu. We saw an uptick in flu during the first quarter. The flu appears to have peaked in March, and overall costs were in line with our expectations. Overall, we continue to see as well as anticipate stable medical cost trends. 
Next, market and product updates. First, we will discuss recent Medicaid activity. 
Washington State. In April, Centene commenced operations under the Apple Foster Care contract in Washington, as the sole provider for this program. The contract is performing in line with expectations, and we anticipate serving over 20,000 foster children. With the addition of this contract, Centene will serve approximately 100,000 Foster Care beneficiaries across all of our markets. 
Nebraska. Also in April, Centene executed a contract with Nebraska as 1 of 3 managed care organizations to administer the state's new Heritage Health program, which covers 230 Medicaid CHIP and ABD enrollees. This contract is expected to commence in the first quarter of 2017. 
Texas. We expect to start CHIP contract in Texas to commence in the latter part of 2016. Centene is the only managed care organization in Texas to participate in all of the state's Medicaid and Medicaid-related product lines. 
Next, Medicaid expansion. At March 31, we served approximately 985,000 Medicaid expansion members in 9 states. This represents an increase of more than 650,000 recipients over the first quarter of 2015. This growth was primarily driven by the addition of Health Net Medicaid expansion members. In January, the Governor of Louisiana signed an Executive Order to expand Medicaid coverage under the ACA. This is expected to be begin in July, and is now included in our updated 2016 guidance. 
Now Medicare and duals. At March 31, we served over 303,000 Medicare and dual beneficiaries. We continue to expect to launch additional Medicare Advantage brands in 4 Centene states in 2017. The new Medicare Advantage brands will be launched under our 4-Star Banner, which will give us the benefit of incremental premium revenues. 
Next, Health Insurance Marketplace. Centene's exchange experience continues to be favorable, and we are achieving margins at the higher end of our targeted range. Our market pre-strategy has been and continues to be focused on targeted low-income, subsidized individuals, many of whom were previously Medicaid-eligible. We designed our exchange solution to be able to leverage our Medicaid platform, including provider networks. In the majority of our markets, we have both Medicaid and market-based product offerings. We coined the term 'churn' to reference those members who can retain coverage through a high-quality, affordable Centene product in either Medicaid or the exchange. In the first quarter, over 90% of our exchange members were subsidy-eligible, this is consistent with 2014 and 2015. 
Centene has maintained a disciplined approach to pricing from day 1. In fact, we are in a net payable position for the 3Rs program. At March 31, we served over 680,000 exchange members across 15 states. At year-end, we expect over 550,000 exchange beneficiaries due to the normal attrition. 
Now Centurion. Our correctional health business continues to successfully expand. At March 31, we served 59,000 correctional members, represent year-over-year growth of 38%. In April, Centurion replaced its existing 1-year contract in Mississippi with a new 3-year contract, which is expected to commence in July. Also in April, we began providing correctional health services in 3 regions in Florida. This marks Centurion's fixed state population. 
Finally, commercial. We ended the first quarter with over 830,000 commercial members. We are fully committed to the success of the existing business, especially in California. However, we have no plans at this time to expand into additional states. 
Shifting gears to our rate output. For Medicaid, we continue to expect the 2016 composite rate adjustment of between 0 and 1%, consistent with the past 2 years. We have known rates for our Medicaid business representing approximately 65% of the projected 2016 member bonds. For Medicare Advantage, final 2017 rates were announced on April 4. These were in line with our expectations of an approximate 1%. 
In conclusion, with first quarter results, we're off to a good start in 2016. We expect this momentum to continue throughout the year. We are on track with our integration of Health Net. Our synergy targets remain $75 million for the first 12 months following the close, and $150 million in the second 12 months following the close. While we remain committed to long-term margin expansion, we continue to expect the 2016 pretax margin to remain relatively flat compared to 2015 as we focus on integration. Our growth pipeline is bigger than ever with the additional products and capabilities in Health Net. We are optimistic about the future and our ability to expand Centene's leadership position in government-sponsored health care. 
As a reminder, our Investor Day is on June 17 in New York City. We look forward to seeing you then. We thank you for your continued interest in Centene. 
Jeff will now provide further details on our first quarter financial results. Jeff?

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good morning. This morning, I will begin with highlighting the results for the first quarter of 2016, and then provide an update on our 2016 full year guidance, including the acquisition of Health Net. First, I would like to high
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good morning. This morning, I will begin with highlighting the results for the first quarter of 2016, and then provide an update on our 2016 full year guidance, including the acquisition of Health Net. 
First, I would like to highlight the effect of the Health Net transaction on the first quarter 2016 results. As previously announced, we completed the acquisition of Health Net on March 24, 2016, for a purchase price of $6 billion, including the assumption of debt. In connection with the completion of the acquisition, we incurred approximately $189 million or $0.83 per diluted share of transaction cost, which includes accelerated stock compensation service, investment banking fees, legal costs and the pertinent value of a $65 million charitable donation under agreements with the U.S. regulatory agencies. Additionally, we have included 8 days of Health Net activity in our first quarter of 2016 results. The 8 days of activity represents approximately $350 million of revenue and had a minimal effect on our HBR, G&A ratio and adjusted diluted earnings per share. 
Now onto the first quarter highlights. For the first quarter, membership of 11.5 million members, an increase of 162% for 2 years driven by the Health Net acquisition. Total revenues were approximately $7 billion, an increase of 36% over Q1 in 2015. Diluted loss per share for the first quarter of 2016 was $0.13, and adjusted diluted earnings per share is $0.74, when excluding Health Net acquisition costs and intangible amortization, compared to $0.55 on an adjusted basis last year. 
In more detail, total revenues grew by $1.8 billion in the first quarter, primarily as a result of expansions or new programs in many of our states in 2015, growth of the Health Insurance Marketplace business, and 8 days of revenue from the Health Net acquisition. Our health benefits ratio was 88.7% in the first quarter of this year compared to 89.8% in last year's first quarter or 88% for the fourth quarter. The 110 basis point decrease year-over-year was also an improvement in the overall HBR for higher-achieving membership particularly long-term care, and growth in the Health Insurance Marketplace membership, which continues to perform well. 
Sequentially, the 70 basis point increase from the fourth quarter reflects [indiscernible] of the flu season which was more fragmented in the first quarter of 2016. For the first quarter, 18% of premium in service revenues came from new visits compared to 23% in the first quarter of 2015. The existing business metrics in the quarter includes Health Net since the acquisition date, and we expect the percentage of revenue from new business to decrease to a single-digit percentage by the end of the year due to the larger revenue base and the denominator. The health benefits ratio for new business were 96 -- 90.6% and 88.3% for existing business in the first quarter. 
The Health Insurance Marketplace product continues to perform well in 2016 with over 680,000 members at March 31. With the addition of Health Net, we continue to be in a net stable position for the risk corridor and risk adjustment components of the 3Rs. As part of our initial asset valuation procedures associated with the acquisition, we have reduced the fixed value of the Health Net in this quarter, and this equals to 0. Additionally, consistent with our historical accounting practice and guidance, we will not report any risk corridors from 2016. Our general and administrative expense ratio was 11.3% in the first quarter this year or 8.3% without the cost associated with the Health Net acquisition compared to 8.3% last year and 8.7% in the fourth quarter, also excluding Health Net acquisition costs. The decrease from the fourth quarter of 2015 reflects the reduction in cost related to global [indiscernible] period with the Health Insurance Marketplace product.
During the first quarter, we incurred $0.02 per diluted share of business expansion cost compared to $0.06 from the prior year. Investment and other income was $15 billion in the first quarter compared with $9 million last year and $8 million in the fourth quarter. Interest expense was $33 million for the first quarter of 2016 compared to $10 million for the first quarter last year, and $11 million in the fourth quarter of last year. The increase is due to the issuance of $2.4 billion of senior notes on February 11, 2016, to fund the cash portion of the consideration for the Health Net acquisition. Consistent with what we have done in the past with managing our balance sheet exposure to short-term interest rates, on March 30, 2016, we introduced the interest rate swap agreements for a notional amount of $1.6 billion converting a substantial portion of our senior notes to a floating rate of interest at the three month LIBOR plus 4.36%. We've acquired tax expense of $17 million on pretax income of $2 million for the first quarter of 2016 due to the non-deductibility of certain Health Net acquisition costs as well as the nondeductibility of the health insured fee. GAAP diluted loss per share from continuing operations for the first quarter was $0.13. Adjusted diluted earnings per share for the first quarter was $0.74. Adjusted diluted earnings per share excludes $0.83 associated with the Health Net acquisition costs and $0.04 associated with the [indiscernible] litigation.
Cash and investments totaled almost $8 billion at quarter-end, including $139 million held by unregulated subsidiaries. We estimate our NAIC risk-based capital percentage to be in excess of 350% of the Authorized Control Level. Debt on March 31 was $4.3 billion, including $515 million of borrowings on our revolver. Our debt-to-capital ratio is 44.3%, excluding our non-recourse mortgage note compared to 34.7% in the fourth quarter of 2015. 
Our medical claim liability totaled $3.9 million at March 31, representing 42 days in claims payable normalizing with the Health Net acquisition. During the first quarter, we made provisional estimates for the fair value of the medical claims liability associated with Health Net. We have not completed our fair valuation exercise, and we announced this certainly could change. Any change to the provisional estimates will be reported as an adjustment to the opening balance sheet and will have no effect on net earnings. Cash flow from operations is $195 million in the first quarter compared to $45 million in the first quarter of 2015. Additionally, you will note that we have adjusted our reporting this quarter to reflect the scale of the business with the new product. We believe this provides meaningful information to investors and will continue to evolve with the complete integration of Health Net. 
This concludes my remarks for the first quarter results. Now I would like to provide an update on our full year guidance. We have adjusted our 2016 guidance to reflect March 2016 closing with the Health Net acquisition. We have lowered the top and bottom end of the revenue guidance by $1 billion, lowered both ends of our adjusted diluted earnings per share guidance by $0.05 to reflect the transaction closing shifting to March 1 from 24. Change in closing date does not have an impact on our run rate revenues or earnings. We now expect total revenues to be between $39 billion and $39.8 billion which represents an increase of approximately 73% of the midpoint of our guidance numbers as compared to 2015. Our 2016 guidance for health benefits ratio is 87% to 87.5%, a decrease from 2015 of approximately 160 basis points at the midpoint of the guidance numbers. 
Reduction in HBR, year-over-year, is due to the addition of Health Net, which operates in the lower HBR due to the higher mix of commercial business and growth in the health insurance marketplace, which operates with a lower HBR and higher G&A ratio. 
General and administrative expense ratio is expected to be between 9.4% and 9.9% in 2016. On an adjusted basis, when excluding acquisition costs, the G&A ratio is expected to increase by 75 basis points between years to 9% to 9.5%. This increase is due to the addition of Health Net, which operates at a higher general administrative  expense ratio due to the mix of business, offset by additional leverage associated with revenue growth and cost savings. 
Other revenue and expense, interest income is forecasted to be between $90 million and $100 million, and interest expense is estimated to be between $180 million to $190 million. We estimate business expansion cost of $0.25 to $0.30 in 2016. We estimate that our effective income tax rate for 2016, excluding noncontrolling interest, will be 55% to 57%. The relatively high effective tax rate reflects the impact of nondeductibility of the health insurer fee and the nondeductibility of certain acquisition costs associated with the Health Net acquisition. In 2016, we anticipate the health insurer fee increases to approximate $450 million. We estimate our diluted shares outstanding to be between 162.5 to 163.5 million shares. In 2016, we expect GAAP diluted earnings per share to be between $2.45 to $2.80, adjusted diluted earnings per share to be between $4 and $4.35. These amounts include Health Net and related synergies for 9 months and 8 days in 2016. Adjusted diluted earnings per share excludes 2 items: first, the amortization of intangible assets associated with the acquisitions which we estimate to be between $0.50 and $0.55 per share; and two, Health Net acquisition-related expenses, which we estimate to be between $1 and $1.05 per diluted share. Additionally, our guidance assumes no receivables with the Affordable Programs and payables for e risk adjusted premium in 2016. 
We believe the guidance we now provided today are generally for participants the financial information, is like a proxy statement adjusted to include only 9 months and 8 days of Health Net activity due to the March 23 closing. We continue to expect $75 million of net synergies in the next 12 months, following closing of this transaction. We estimate our operating cash flow to be between 1.5 to 2x net earnings. 
That concludes my remarks. And operator, you may now open the lines for questions.

componenttext: I think -- there are couple of elements. One, we do not participate in any processes or auctions, whatever you call it, today. So to the extent that is, we're out of that. Two, the controlling issue, particularly in the Medicare-related business, will be the network. If they have a network that's not in our sweet spot, which is at the lower social economic level, then we won't have any interest in it. So we have so much organic opportunity. I mean our pipeline is very robust, and I'm not -- we're not really of the mind that we need that to meet our growth targets. If it's there and it makes sense, we'll do it.

componenttext: Well, I think -- United -- and I have a lot of respect for Steve Hemsley, and his people and what they do and their approach to things. To the extent that they have a membership that would fit within ours -- our model, sure we take them on, but I'm not anticipating any large gain from that either just because of the differences.

componenttext: Well, obviously, we believe it's going well. And once again, I've -- in many conferences, I've commented that it's a $700 billion category, of which 65% is at 400% of the federal poverty level and lower. And that's our sweet spot. And that's where our networks are now. And so to the extent and that's why when people ask about some things that others may have to give up, we question the network that they serve. But we think we have in place a network that population prefers to use, and we're just expanded, very candidly. When you're in Medicare, you have more orthopedic surgeons and other things that affect more of the elderly population. And so we're throwing that out, as appropriate, and we have a strong team doing it.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Maybe one granular question and then one big picture one. In the Q1 cost trend, obviously, your MLR year-to-year improved nicely. As a lot of the managed care companies and providers for that matter calling out leap year and Easter, and you said that flu was in line with your expectations. How about those 2 dynamics? And how much of an impact did they have? Did they offset each other, in your view? Any comments there?

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Jeff. I mean, I think the way we always look at leap year is, it's just an extra day of medical costs when we do our forecasting, when we put our budget together. I think Easter may have had a slightly favorable impact to that, but the way we
componenttext: Yes. This is Jeff. I mean, I think the way we always look at leap year is, it's just an extra day of medical costs when we do our forecasting, when we put our budget together. I think Easter may have had a slightly favorable impact to that, but the way we really forecasted it was just we include an extra day of medical costs in the quarter. So again, I think the improvement that you're seeing is referenced to the complex care and additionally the growth in the Medicaid expansion. Obviously, -- excuse me, the health insurance marketplace products, right? And they carry a lot lower HBR than our average.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sure. Then maybe a bigger picture. There's a lot of -- there's moving parts this year even more than usual. There is always a lot of opportunities and some challenges. I wonder, if you look at the guidance that you now are blessing and reiterating w
componenttext: Sure. Sure. Then maybe a bigger picture. There's a lot of -- there's moving parts this year even more than usual. There is always a lot of opportunities and some challenges. I wonder, if you look at the guidance that you now are blessing and reiterating with the exception of the 3.5-week delay on the deal, would you point to 1 or 2 things that look like might be -- if you end up beating the estimates coming ahead of the estimates that those would be the likely sources of potential upside? And is there 1 or 2 things that are -- are the challenges you faced as you look out to the rest of the year?

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, forgive me, I think if we saw something, it would certainly be one-sided.  I think you could adjust the value in line with that. So there's no one thing that we can call out. Jeff [indiscernible] and wishes. And the only thing I'd call out that i
componenttext: I think, forgive me, I think if we saw something, it would certainly be one-sided.  I think you could adjust the value in line with that. So there's no one thing that we can call out. Jeff [indiscernible] and wishes. And the only thing I'd call out that is a positive or negative. But as I've talked about historically, we have a size and a scale that -- we're in 24, 25 states, growing the number. 280  -- 260 different contracts within those states. At any given time, you'll have one contract in the state that's an issue, and you'll have a couple that are offsetting it. So it's the security and stability of diversification. And so that's why that's what makes its so hard to call out any one particular thing because I'd like to think there's no one issue that can have a total deleterious effect on the whole company. I hope that helps.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Sarah James of Wedbush Securities.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to circle back to the exchange risk mix. It looked like in the Q, risk adjusters were up about 120% versus the combined Centene Health Net at year-end. And it's 680,000 enrollment, I was getting up about 36% from the 500,000 range you previously
componenttext: I wanted to circle back to the exchange risk mix. It looked like in the Q, risk adjusters were up about 120% versus the combined Centene Health Net at year-end. So I'm just trying to understand the delta there between the degree to which risk adjusters went up versus the degree to which enrollment went up.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes. This is Jeff. I think you're correct. The risk adjustment, the liability payable did increase during the quarter. I would say that, that is a function of -- we're seeing the same kind of member demographics that we've seen consistently. And as you're aware, we've been in a risk adjustment payable for the last 2 years. So adding additional member volume has really just increased that risk adjustment payable.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: To date, there's only been just symptomatic flu-type cases of Zika. There's not really been a case of the catastrophic consequences except for one in Hawaii. We are -- we're tracking that. The projections of Zika are really unpredictable based on Latin Am
componenttext: To date, there's only been just symptomatic flu-type cases of Zika. There's not really been a case of the catastrophic consequences except for one in Hawaii. We are -- we're tracking that. The projections of Zika are really unpredictable based on Latin American experience, but we are optimistic that the government's position or federal chief's position that the burden -- the disease burden on United States should be very small. It's probably very accurate and the cost of testing or visit should be relatively minimal.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I just wanted a starting point, but that's fine. And then just lastly, on the Medicare expansion. I know you guys have talked about the 4 new markets. What does success look like? What sort of critical mass do you need? Or should we think of this as
componenttext: Okay. I just wanted a starting point, but that's fine. And then just lastly, on the Medicare expansion. I know you guys have talked about the 4 new markets. What does success look like? What sort of critical mass do you need? Or should we think of this as existing Medicaid markets, so infrastructure maybe more in place, you don't necessarily have to see a big ramp in membership to make those plans successful next year?

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the infrastructure, of course, is in place, and the advantage we have is that we have very strong decentralized plans that the -- if you were to coin a word out, our local CEOs and their teams now have their indigenized product in their market, be
componenttext: I think the infrastructure, of course, is in place, and the advantage we have is that we have very strong decentralized plans that the -- if you were to coin a word out, our local CEOs and their teams now have their indigenized product in their market, because you don't just take something from California, and parachute it in right out. So there's that aspect of it. I think the thing that we're cognizant of in thinking about is there are different acquisition costs in Medicare products. It's something some of us have done historically understand. So it would take a -- it will not take a gigantic amount of critical mass to start to see and provide some margin to us. But I expect in the first few quarters to have some expense that -- well, not necessarily be fully offset by the revenue and that's something we'll get more into at year-end when we have the specifics and give guidance on '17, as we always do.

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Michael, what's the -- so then just on that, what's the network strategy? I assume you'll need to augment your networks for different providers in the Medicare business versus Medicaid. And I'm curious what your thought is on rates. Are paying off of
componenttext: And Michael, what's the -- so then just on that, what's the network strategy? I assume you'll need to augment your networks for different providers in the Medicare business versus Medicaid. And I'm curious what your thought is on rates. Are paying off of Medicare fee schedule? Or do you think you can look something more like Medicaid?

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it will be a combination, depending on the particular services. I mean we're going to, as I said earlier, I think you're going to find -- you got to have more orthopedic surgeons type. You're going to have neonatologists. You're going to hav
componenttext: Well, I think it will be a combination, depending on the particular services. I mean we're going to, as I said earlier, I think you're going to find -- you got to have more orthopedic surgeons type. You're going to have neonatologists. You're going to have certain -- you may have more of rheumatologists. Those things and some of those subspecialties. I expect the rates will be higher than the Medicaid level because we're not using them much in Medicaid. We're not driving the volume there. So it's a matter of just being very surgical, as we've demonstrated before, but the primary care will take -- will be our current network, and we'll adjust the rates as we see appropriate against the -- as we do now with exchange versus Medicaid. But it's all in line with providing adequate, equitable reimbursement and protecting our margins.

componenttext: Yes. The question is, if we get something back, and yes, it ultimately would. headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then looks like you had a fairly big increase in the return of premium payable on the balance sheet. I think it went up to about $579 million. It had been running at a couple of hundred million. Is that just the addition of sort of Health Net? And is that all rebate dollars? And does that just reflect sort of California coming on and the rebate back from the Medicaid expansion?

headline: Centene Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, that's -- you're correct. It is the addition of Health Net. I think if you look at Health Net's 10-K they've disclosed that over the last couple of years, they've had increases in their MLR rebate payable in the California business, specifically
componenttext: Yes, yes, that's -- you're correct. It is the addition of Health Net. I think if you look at Health Net's 10-K they've disclosed that over the last couple of years, they've had increases in their MLR rebate payable in the California business, specifically related to the Medicaid expansion. So that's all driven by that amount. I think the dollar amount of the rebate is somewhere north of $400 million on rebates for the Medicaid expansion business for Health Net in California.

componenttext: Yes -- no, I'm not going to get into any specifics again. So I mean, realistically, we should only be responsible for 8 days of March, right? So that's the work that we're looking to complete in the second quarter.
