Good morning, and welcome to the Centene Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Financial Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Ed Kroll, Senior Vice President, Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Denise, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Jeff Schwaneke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Of
componenttext:
Thank you, Denise, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. Michael Neidorff, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Jeff Schwaneke, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Centene Corporation, will host this morning's call.
The call may also be accessed through our website at centene.com. A replay will be available shortly after the call's completion, also at centene.com or by dialing (877) 344-7529 in the U.S. and Canada or in other countries by dialing (412) 317-0088. The playback code for both of those dial playbacks is 10093224.
Any remarks that Centene may make about future expectations, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provision under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by these forward-looking statements as a result of various important factors, including those discussed in Centene's most recently filed Form 10-Q, which is dated today, October 25, 2016, or the most recent Form 10-K dated February 22, 2016; and other public SEC filings.
Centene anticipates that subsequent events and developments will cause its estimates to change. While the company may elect to update these forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, Michael Neidorff. Michael?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. During the course of this morning's call, we will discuss our third quarter results and provide an update on Centene's markets and products. Addit
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Centene's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. During the course of this morning's call, we will discuss our third quarter results and provide an update on Centene's markets and products. Additionally, we will bring you up-to-date on the Health Net integration.
Let me begin with a few comments on Health Net. As part of our ongoing fair value analysis, during the second quarter, we recorded a premium deficiency reserve of approximately $300 million due to unfavorable performance in some of Health Net's business operations. The PDR covers the period March 24 to December 31, 2016. We have taken significant actions over the past few months to improve the business operations through 2017 and beyond. These include price increases, plan design changes and certain market exits. We fully believe we have now dealt with all the factors that contributed to the PDR.
During the third quarter, we reduced the $300 million PDR to $285 million as the outlook of substance abuse claims liability in California has improved. Please note this had no effect on third quarter earnings. The largest component of the PDR is $110 million related to the California commercial business. We negotiated with the California Department of Insurance the necessary benefit changes. On October 3, we submitted our filings to the CDI called the 2017 plan designs and rate adjustments. These substantial benefit design changes allowed us to reduce our original 23% rate increase to 9.9%. Some of the key benefit changes included: the first-time inclusion of an out-of-network deductible for platinum and gold plans, $5000 for an individual and $10,000 for a family; a significant increase in the out-of-network maximum out-of-pocket level to $25,000 for an individual and $50,000 for a family; the elimination of non-emergent out-of-state coverage and travel network access; the elimination of the default rate of 75% of billed charges for out-of-network services that do not have a Medicare rate; the reduction of reimbursement for out-of-network physicians and other services and supplies to 100% of the Medicare rate from the 85the percentile of FAIR Health and 190% of the Medicare rate, respectively; and restrictions on third-party premium payments, which were not included the original 2016 offering. We believe these subsequent changes will significantly strengthen our control of out-of-network utilization, which was the main driver of the PPO cost issues. In addition, we expect to further improve the operating performance of these products with the implementation of Centene's medical management tools as well as network enhancements. We appreciate the collaboration efforts of the CDI through the process. We expect the rate and benefit design changes to create a more competitive product in 2017 and allow for a balanced book of business.
Let me now go through the remaining components of the PDR and the corrective actions we have taken outside of California. First, $70 million related to Arizona individual commercial. We were exit the Arizona individual PPO business effective January 1, 2017. This exit represents $32 million of the $70 million loss. The remaining $38 million of the loss is associated with the individual HMO exchange product in Arizona. We have reconfigured our geographic presence, increased rates and redesign benefits. We will remain in Pima County and in Maricopa County as the only carrier. We expect the Arizona exchange to generate $500 million in incremental revenue and operate within our normal marketplace margins in 2017.
Second, $15 million related to Arizona Medicaid. As of July 1, this business has been fully transitioned to Centene's operating platform. We expect Arizona Medicaid to be profitable next year.
Third, $20 million related to other smaller items, including the Arizona small group and Oregon individual business. We have applied for rate increases and benefit design changes to address these issues.
And lastly, $70 million related to Medicare Advantage. We submitted bids in June and are taking actions on unit cost and medical management initiatives to achieve profitability next year.
Next, let's talk about Health Net integration. The integration process continues to go well, and we remain on track or ahead of schedule in many areas. We have now completed the actions needed to capture all the $75 million first year synergy target.
During the third quarter, we began the conversion of Health Net's California plan on to Centene's medical management system. We expect this conversion to help drive better operating performance through the application of Centene's award-winning case management tools and programs.
Turning to third quarter financials. Membership at quarter end was 11.4 million members, representing an increase of 6.6 million beneficiaries over the third quarter of 2015. Total revenue increased 86% year-over-year to $10.8 billion. On a sequential basis, total revenues declined by $50 million due to exchange membership attrition and the eligibility redetermine process in California Medicaid. This is partially offset by a commencement of Medicaid expansion in Louisiana, and all of these were expected. Note the redetermine results in a sequential loss of approximately 61,000 Medicaid beneficiaries in this state. It has now been completed and roughly 16,000 members were added in October. The HBR improved 200 basis points year-over-year to 87%. This was primarily attributable to the commercial product mix shift from Health Net. Importantly, we continue to see stable medical cost trends and systems with our expectations in the low single digits.
Lastly, on a GAAP basis, we reported diluted earnings per share of $0.84. We reported adjusted diluted earnings per share of $1.11 or $1.16 when excluding a $0.05 expense related to the 2015 risk adjustment and reinsurance reconciliation under the Affordable Care Act. Recall that in the second quarter, we recorded a $0.19 diluted EPS benefit related to this reconciliation. Thus, the net benefit we have recorded in the past 2 months is actually $0.14. Jeff will provide further financial details, including updated 2016 guidance. 
Now on to market and product update. First, we will discuss recent Medicaid activity. In August, Centene was 1 of 3 brands selected to serve long-term care recipients in Northern Pennsylvania's Healthy -- HealthChoice program statewide. This program covers more than 420,000 individuals who are duly eligible and those with physical disabilities. This contract will be rolled out in 3 tranches. The Southwest zone will be the first to go live with an expected start date of July 1, 2017. The Southeast zone is expected to commence January of 2018, and the remainder of the state is expected to begin on January 1, 2019. Pennsylvania marks Centene's 10th state managing long-term care for long-term care beneficiaries. We are the largest provider of long-term care support services. We are the fastest-growing segment of the managed care market. Where the contract has been -- not been finalized, we expect it will ramp up and be profitable within a normal time frame. 
Alabama. In September, the Alabama legislation approved the funding needed to create its regional care organization structure. Centene's specialty solutions division involved has contracted with 5 nonprofit RCOs in the state to provide management services. Operations are expected to commence July 1, 2017. This award highlights Centene's depth and breadth of management services under our involved plan. 
Missouri. Last week, we were pleased to be selected to provide managed care services to Medicaid recipients in all 114 counties in Missouri. This award is a successful reprocurement and expansion of Centene's presence in the state. This expanded program covers over 240,000 additional Medicaid beneficiaries in Missouri, bringing the total number of individuals covered to over 740,000. The program is expected to commence May 1, 2017. 
Next, Medicare and duals. At quarter end, we served over 300,000 Medicare and dual beneficiaries. We continue to move forward with our growth plan to expand our Medicare Advantage footprint into Centene's Medicaid states next year. We are launching new MA plan in Texas, Florida and Mississippi. These new plans will be launched under our 4-STAR parent [ph] rating and are eligible for a 5% premium bonus. In Georgia, we're using our existing special needs plans to launch Medicare Advantage. This plan will also be eligible through quality bonus. Consistent with Centene's overall strategy, we will focus on low-income Medicare beneficiaries. We fully expect to have a profitable MA business in 2017.
Let me make a brief comment on the recently announced 2018 Medicare Advantage STAR ratings. We are pleased to have maintained our 4-STAR parent [ph] rating. 7 of our plans are an improved -- have improvement in STAR ratings and 7 plan STAR ratings stayed the same. Our Oregon plan STAR rating declined from 4 to 3.5 stars, primarily due to a reduction in Part D scores. This was the result of the addition of a deductible to our prescription drug benefit, which was done to improve profitability. This issue was limited to the Oregon market. Maintaining a high-quality STAR rating is a top priority for Centene. 
Now Health Insurance Marketplace. Centene's exchange experience continues to be favorable, and we are achieving margins at the high end of our targeted range. Our marketplace strategy is different from most of our peers. We design our exchange solutions to be able to leverage our Medicaid platform, including provider networks, as we are focused on low-income subsidized individuals. In the third quarter, over 90% of our exchange revenues were subsidy-eligible. This is consistent with our prior experience. We ended the quarter with over 580,000 exchange members in 15 states. We continue to anticipate serving approximately 550 exchange members at year-end through the normal attrition. Overall, we continue to expect our marketplace offerings to be profitable next year. 
Shifting gears to our rate outlook. For Medicaid, we continue to expect in 2016 composite rate adjustment of between 0% and 1%, consistent with the past few years.
In summary, we are optimistic about the future of our ability to expand Centene's leadership position in government-sponsored health care. We are on track with the integration of Health Net. We have taken the necessary actions to substantially improve the underperforming markets and products covered by the 2016 PDR. Our growth pipeline is bigger than ever, and we have continued to expand our Medicare Advantage market. We remain committed to long-term margin expansion and continue to make the necessary investments in systems and infrastructure to successfully execute our strategy. As a reminder, our next Investor Day is on December 16 in New York City. As is our custom, we will provide full first-time 2017 financial guidance. 
I would like to make a couple of comments on our expectations for 2017. At this time, we believe total revenues will be approximately $46 billion at a minimum. This represents a $1 billion increase over the estimate we provided at the June Investor Day and a 15% increase over 2016. Importantly, the outlook continues to be favorable despite the fact that the denominator is significantly larger. Equally, while we are still finalizing our annual operating plan for '17, we have no reason to believe that the consensus estimate for '17 will be outside our target range.
Thank you for your interest in Centene. Jeff will now provide further details on our third quarter financial results.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael, and good morning. This morning, I will begin with highlighting the results for the third quarter of 2016 and provide an update on our 2016 full year guidance.For the third quarter 2016, Centene's membership was 11.4 million members,
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael, and good morning. This morning, I will begin with highlighting the results for the third quarter of 2016 and provide an update on our 2016 full year guidance.
For the third quarter 2016, Centene's membership was 11.4 million members, an increase of 137% between years, driven by the Health Net acquisition. Total revenues were $10.8 billion, an increase of 86% over Q3 of 2015. Diluted earnings per share for the third quarter of 2016 was $0.84 compared to $0.75 last year, and adjusted diluted earnings per share for the third quarter of 2016 was $1.11 compared to $0.87 last year.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share include the charge of $0.05 per diluted share associated with the Arizona risk adjustment program. During the third quarter, we received information from CMS that some of the participants in the Arizona risk adjustment program were unable to pay the amounts owed to the federal government associated with the 2015 risk adjustment reconciliation. As a result, the uncollected risk adjustment amount was prorated to all insurers in the market. Accordingly, we recorded a charge of $0.05 per diluted share, recognizing our portion of the risk adjustment that will not be collected, which reduces the $0.19 per diluted share benefit we recorded in the second quarter of 2016.
Now for some more specifics. Total revenues grew year-over-year by $5 billion in the third quarter, primarily as a result of the Health Net acquisition, expansions or new programs in many of our states in 2015 and '16 and growth in the Health Insurance Marketplace business in 2016. Sequentially, our revenues were slightly lower than the second quarter due to lower commercial membership, primarily as a result of the expected attrition in the Health Insurance Marketplace business and lower membership in the California Medicaid program as a result of annual eligibility redeterminations completed by the state. This was partially offset by growth in other markets, specifically in Louisiana Medicaid expansion. Our health benefits ratio was 87% in the third quarter this year compared to 89% in last year's third quarter and 86.6% in the second quarter of 2016. The 200 basis point decrease year-over-year results from the addition of Health Net as well as the growth in the Health Insurance Marketplace business, both of which operate at a lower HBR. Sequentially, the 40 basis point increase in the second quarter reflects normal seasonality in the business.
We continue to deliver strong membership and margins in the Health Insurance Marketplace business during the third quarter. The product continues to achieve margins at the high end of our targeted range, and we now have over $329 million accrued as a risk adjustment payable for services provided in 2016. For 2016, we continue to record reinsurance at the 50% coinsurance rate, record no risk corridor receivable and record the risk adjustment utilizing the information we received from the data aggregators consistent with 2015. Our general and administrative expense ratio was 9.2% in the third quarter of this year or 9.1% excluding the cost associated with the Health Net acquisition compared to 8.4% in the third quarter of last year and 9% in the second quarter of this year, also excluding Health Net acquisition cost. The increase year-over-year reflects the addition of the Health Net business, which operates at a higher G&A ratio due to a greater mix of commercial business. Sequentially, the 10 basis point increase is due to lower revenue in the third quarter. During the third quarter, we incurred $0.07 per diluted share of business expansion costs, primarily associated with the Texas STAR Kids award and the 2017 Medicare expansion, compared to $0.05 per diluted share in the prior year.
Investment and other income was $33 million in the third quarter of 2016 compared to $8 million for the third quarter last year and $32 million in the second quarter of this year. The increase year-over-year is a result of the larger investment balances associated with the Health Net acquisition. Interest expense was $57 million for the third quarter of 2016 compared to $11 million for the third quarter last year and $52 million in the second quarter of this year. The increase year-over-year is primarily due to the financing associated with the Health Net transaction. The sequential increase is due to the full quarter effect of the $500 million of additional senior notes we issued in June of 2016. Our tax rate for the quarter was 53.8% compared to 48.3% in the prior year. The higher tax rate is driven by the acquisition of Health Net.
During the third quarter, we received approval of a refund in connection with our tax position with respect to 162(m)(6) or the limitation on the deductibility of certain executive compensation. As a reminder, we expect to be subject to 162(m)(6) limitation in 2017 as a result of the Health Net acquisition.
GAAP diluted earnings per share for continuing operations for the third quarter was $0.84, and adjusted diluted earnings per share for the third quarter was $1.11. Both amounts include a $0.05 diluted earnings per share charge associated with the Arizona risk adjustment program previously discussed. As a reminder, adjusted diluted earnings per share excludes $0.12 associated with the Health Net acquisition cost and $0.15 associated with intangible amortization.
Cash and investments totaled $8.1 billion at quarter end, including $268 million held by unregulated subsidiaries. We estimate our risk-based capital percentage for NAIC filers to be in excess of 350% of the authorized control level.
Debt on September 30 was $4.6 billion, including $300 million of borrowings on our revolver. Our debt-to-capital ratio was 44.1%, excluding our nonrecourse mortgage note compared to 44.4% at the second quarter of 2016.
Our medical claim liability totaled $3.8 billion at September 30, representing 41 days in claims payable. The days and claims payable decreased during the third quarter due to annual provider risk share settlements of approximately $115 million in our California market as well as the timing of the claims payments at the end of the quarter.
We had strong operating cash flow for the third quarter of $480 million or 3.3x net earnings. This was primarily driven by net earnings, collection of outstanding capitation payments and prepayment of amounts from CMS associated with the Medicare product. This was partially offset by payment of the health insurer fee of $513 million at quarter end. 
A quick update on the substance abuse claims. During the third quarter, we revised our estimate of the level of substance abuse cost we anticipated to incur between the acquisition date and the end of the year. As you recall, we established a reserve of $50 million in our acquisition accounting in the second quarter as an estimate of the liability associated with these claims for the period from March 24 through December 31, 2016. Based on the level of incurred and projected claims through the third quarter, we have lowered our estimate from $50 million to $35 million. This adjustment had no effect on earnings. We continue to evaluate the fair valuation associated with the substance abuse claims and expect to complete that analysis in the fourth quarter.
As Michael mentioned in his comments, we have taken actions associated with products that were included in the PDR, including product design, premium rates, product exits and numerous medical management and network initiatives. Based on the action we have taken, we believe we have resolved the issues associated with the 2016 premium deficiency reserve for 2017. We look forward to providing more details and full 2017 guidance in our normal December Investor Day.
Lastly, an update on our 2016 full year guidance. As described in our press release this morning, we are adjusting our guidance for the risk adjustment charge related to the Arizona recognized in the third quarter. As we previously disclosed, during the second quarter of 2016, we recorded a benefit of $0.19 per diluted share and increased our full year guidance for the 2015 reconciliation of the risk adjustment and reinsurance provisions of the marketplace business at that time. As a result of the information received from CMS in the third quarter, the benefit recorded in the second quarter was reduced by $0.05 per diluted share to $0.14 when combining both quarters. We have updated our 2016 guidance accordingly. Our updated annual guidance is as follows: total revenues of $39.4 billion to $40 billion; GAAP diluted earnings per share of $2.73 to $2.83; adjusted diluted earnings per share of $4.28 to $4.38; G&A ratio of 9.4% to 9.9%; the G&A ratio excluding the transaction cost of 9% to 9.5%; and effective income tax rate of 54.5% to 56.5%; and diluted shares outstanding of 162.5 million to 163.5 million shares. The guidance above implies a fourth quarter GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.83 to $0.93 and an adjusted diluted earnings per share of $1.05 to $1.15. This range now includes business expansion costs, which we expect to be at the high end of our guidance range of $0.25 to $0.30 in the fourth quarter, driven by increased costs associated with our expected Health Insurance Marketplace growth in 2017. We continue to estimate our operating cash flow on a long-term basis to be between 1.5 and 2x net earnings. As previously highlighted in the second quarter, we do anticipate that there will be variability in our cash flow from quarter-to-quarter, depending on the timing of payments to certain states associated with minimum MLR programs, primarily in California. Subsequent to quarter end, we received amendments to our California contracts with the Department of Health Care Services to amend the Medicaid expansion Medical Loss Ratio definition. All reconciliation periods remain open. However, we expect the amendment to reduce our minimum MLR liability and are currently working with the state to evaluate the impact in the amendment.
That concludes my remarks. And operator, you may now open the line for questions.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

And so I'm curious, your margins are still running below your long-term goals. Is there some sort of conservatism in there? I would've expected it with some of the synergies, and it sounds like you're assuming the full $300 million of Health Net comes back. Are there some headwinds from a margin perspective? Or is this just sort of a conservative place to start?

componenttext: I think at this stage, in our AOP, annual operating plan process, it's a safe place to be. So we're going through the final process. We're looking at start-up costs with the various new products we have, et cetera. And so we really -- outside our pattern, I'm not saying much or any about earnings until the December call. But we thought that with all the things out there, we would give some indication. And then we'll give you a lot of granularity and a lot more color in December, Josh.

componenttext: This is a pure HMO. It's -- we have the right rates, the right positioning. It's one that has been very successful for us in other markets, and we really -- we exited the PPO in those and the HMO Health Net had was not as well structured. And so we're confident that it will be profitable. Do you want to anything, Jesse?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Josh. This is Jesse Hunter. So just a couple of things. One, we will be the sole carrier for the Maricopa County on the exchange but not in Pima County. We'll be 1 of 2 in Pima County. So I think it is important to provide a little bit of context for
componenttext: Yes, Josh. This is Jesse Hunter. So just a couple of things. One, we will be the sole carrier for the Maricopa County on the exchange but not in Pima County. We'll be 1 of 2 in Pima County. So I think it is important to provide a little bit of context for Arizona marketplace just in general. I think the starting point for the whole market was off, right, so that's where what drove a lot of the carrier exits. You had grandmother in your policies. You had a number of other things. So Health Net had that experience. That experience has been fully reflected in our plan for 2017. In addition, we had that in new products. We are -- particularly in Maricopa County, we've added a new silver and a new bronze and better product, which is consistent with what we have in the other Centene and better markets. So that's -- those are the kinds of things that give us a lot more confidence around kind of leveraging the Centene marketplace experience versus the historical Arizona marketplace experience.

componenttext: Okay, a couple of things. One, I think the state handled it wisely. There was a court case. And rather than appealing an appeal, they drag it out. They said let's do a new RFP. So as we continue to look at that, we'll have to evaluate that as we get closer to the end of the year specifically for 2016 and where everybody stands.

I think importantly, last time, when we had the $0.19, we just added it, right, and didn't try and take any credit for it as part of the normal earnings and just we added the full $0.19 in. And so this really amounts to easily an adjustment of $0.19 by $0.05 that we didn't get. So it's once again, I think, a very balanced approach. I almost wish we have a separate line but accounting rules don't allow that.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris, this is Jesse. So I think we -- as we said in our June Investor Day when we talked about our launch of -- it's actually 4 new MA products in our existing markets. But we talked about this as a proof of concept. So we definitely are taking a ki
componenttext: Yes, Chris, this is Jesse. So I think we -- as we said in our June Investor Day when we talked about our launch of -- it's actually 4 new MA products in our existing markets. But we talked about this as a proof of concept. So we definitely are taking a kind of softer launch approach for 2017, so we can be in a position to then grow from that base within those 4 markets in 2018 and forward but then also entering other markets in MA in 2018. So we'll see kind of a continued progression, but we're looking at our growth in MA as a multiyear strategy.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we commented at the Investor Day, it's no different than how we entered the marketplace. You go in it carefully. You prove the concept. And then you -- once you get comfortable with it, you turn up the heat on it. And that's what worked for u
componenttext: Yes, I think we commented at the Investor Day, it's no different than how we entered the marketplace. You go in it carefully. You prove the concept. And then you -- once you get comfortable with it, you turn up the heat on it. And that's what worked for us. And we've always said it's not how fast but how well. And so we're applying that same principle to this product.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the synergies, I get a little turned around sometimes in terms of where things exactly stand for this year versus what we should expect for next year. So is the right amount that's actually going to be realized in sort of earnings t
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the synergies, I get a little turned around sometimes in terms of where things exactly stand for this year versus what we should expect for next year. So is the right amount that's actually going to be realized in sort of earnings this year, $50 million to $55 million, and then next year you get the residual? And have you seen any upside to the original target at this point?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start and Jeff can pick up. We always talked about the $75 million would be the first 12 months of operation. So you have the -- this year, you have roughly 9 months of it. I think, Jeff, it was about $15 million in that range? So why don't you
componenttext: Well, I'll start and Jeff can pick up. We always talked about the $75 million would be the first 12 months of operation. So you have the -- this year, you have roughly 9 months of it. I think, Jeff, it was about $15 million in that range? So why don't you...

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. I mean, I think if you just kind of take the -- we said the first 12 months, $75 million; second 12 months, $150 million. And I think if you just take that and assume a March transaction date and shift that out, I mean, there is obvious
componenttext: Yes, that's right. I mean, I think if you just kind of take the -- we said the first 12 months, $75 million; second 12 months, $150 million. And I think if you just take that and assume a March transaction date and shift that out, I mean, there is obviously, just based on the fiscal year. So that's what we indicated is that we've executed on all the actions to get to $75 million within the first 12 months and only 9 of those months fall into 2016. So you're correct is it that, that benefit will continue obviously into '17, and then there's additional synergy capture there as well that we're confident that we can achieve.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to the Health Net PPO and EPO product in California. Can you justify a frame level of losses that you expect to continue into 2017 here? I know the rate hike and benefit design changes are obviously going to significantly reduce a lot. But even
componenttext: Going back to the Health Net PPO and EPO product in California. Can you justify a frame level of losses that you expect to continue into 2017 here? I know the rate hike and benefit design changes are obviously going to significantly reduce a lot. But even in the rate filing itself, do you have a predicted pretax loss of around $40 million. Can you talk about, one, what are the upside to that $40 million loss from benefit designs changes or medical management? And also, does the rate filing itself reflect the $50 million reduction in the PDR-related substance abuse that you announced today?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jesse will start there now.
componenttext: Jesse will start there now.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as we look out into '17 -- first of all, the rate filing would account for some decreased substance abuse utilization. As far as the $42 million, you're correct, that was in the rate filing. And we are taking and continue to take medical mana
componenttext: Yes, I think as we look out into '17 -- first of all, the rate filing would account for some decreased substance abuse utilization. As far as the $42 million, you're correct, that was in the rate filing. And we are taking and continue to take medical management network initiatives. And at this point in time, we believe we've covered more than half of that, and we're not done. And we think we have continued actions that we can take between now and next year to give us closer to the breakeven point.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Yes, yes, I'm sure we would. I think what's important here is that rate filing was based on the actual assumptions on the experience -- the historic experience as well, which is part of the requirement. And so you file that and it -- we have all the benefit and other changes, some of which is studded in there. So we went from 57 to 40. But then as all the other things will do, and we believe, as Jeff just said, we'll get it to breakeven, and based on the population we attract, being able to have lower premiums, we need to do better than that. But that's for discussion later in the year as it unfolds.

And then what's your expectation for next year?

componenttext: Yes, so if you look at this -- I mean, this was disclosed, I think, in Health Net's 2015 10-K. But I think the settlement account effectively had a surplus of over $300 million or something in that range. And again, as a reminder, the Medicaid expansion business is a component of that settlement agreement. And so I guess, what I would say is that, that number has continued to build over time, and I don't think this settlement agreement is going to have an impact.

componenttext: Okay. And then can you tell us your insurer fee revenues have been less than the expenses for the insurer fee recently. Can you tell us why that -- that's going on? Why is it higher, reflecting the gross up?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so just a quick thing. The accounting rules require that if the insurance fee is billed as one premium, it's in premium revenue. So for example, in Medicare, the insurer fee is actually embedded in the revenue line, in premium revenue line; whereas
componenttext: Well, so just a quick thing. The accounting rules require that if the insurance fee is billed as one premium, it's in premium revenue. So for example, in Medicare, the insurer fee is actually embedded in the revenue line, in premium revenue line; whereas for medicaid, it's a separate component of the rate, and it's actually billed separately. So it's shown separately. And so that's just an accounting technicality there. Same thing for marketplace, by the way.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Sort of the last question, if you don't mind. What's left to do on the California PPO business? You talk about continuing to focus on it. From your commentary, it doesn't seem like that's quite yet to profitability for next year. So what are th
componenttext: All right. Sort of the last question, if you don't mind. What's left to do on the California PPO business? You talk about continuing to focus on it. From your commentary, it doesn't seem like that's quite yet to profitability for next year. So what are the things that you can do over the next year to try to improve the profitability of that?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we are going to -- you're going to see us putting emphasis on growing it on a very balanced book of business. The previous design I would almost characterize as an inexpensive indemnity type product. And it was a for Health Net in 2015 as we
componenttext: Well, I think we are going to -- you're going to see us putting emphasis on growing it on a very balanced book of business. The previous design I would almost characterize as an inexpensive indemnity type product. And it was a for Health Net in 2015 as well, we knew that. But I think when we look at it, we have the right rate structure, the right benefit structure to attract a balanced book of business to drive the utilization in network, which is intended. The out-of-network is -- should be exception, not the primary use of it. So we've done all those things. And I think now it's just starting to grow in the right way and market it, and we will return it to the place it deserves to be.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will be from David Windley of Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question will be from David Windley of Jefferies.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to the California PDR exposure. So I just want to understand kind of the 2 pieces. On the substance abuse side, am I understanding correctly that your exposure there -- obviously a decline in the update this quarter. But your exposure
componenttext: I wanted to go back to the California PDR exposure. So I just want to understand kind of the 2 pieces. On the substance abuse side, am I understanding correctly that your exposure there -- obviously a decline in the update this quarter. But your exposure into 2017 is mitigated or eliminated by your change in certificate coverage, i.e., you don't have to pay those types of claims going into next year? And then rate and benefit design are what you're using to attack the other $75 million? Is that the right way to think about it, or is there a blurry your line?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think when you look at the -- when you look at all the products associated with it, the out-of-network coverage, the benefit design they had before was without the Medicare maximum. And the other issues where it was a percent of billed charges, they
componenttext: No, I think when you look at the -- when you look at all the products associated with it, the out-of-network coverage, the benefit design they had before was without the Medicare maximum. And the other issues where it was a percent of billed charges, they could be out-of-network. Providers could do what they wanted. And we're LIBOR at the time for 75% of billed charges till they change the certificate it covers. So virtually putting in the changes that I discussed during my formal remarks eliminate the incentives that put people into that product at the same level. And we already see a material drop-off of that taking place. It was a bad design before. The state everybody recognized that. It's been fully fixed, and there's other steps taking place that let the legal authorities deal with as it relates to it. So that affects that. It also affects the normal PPO. I cited before the same principle applies. We now have a product that will have great appeal, the people who want to use our in-network and who are in some [indiscernible] on that is out of network. I mean, they now have an exposure of $25,000 maximum out of pocket, which is significantly greater than what it was but very competitive. So it's really -- we now have the right PPO design. And PPOs have always been intended for in-network use without a network being exception. Before, virtually all the utilization was out of network. So we believe that, that together with the lower rate increase will be more attractive to the balanced book of business. These are things we've done successfully for many years and will really -- will turn this around. And when it has and will put us where we want to be.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Michael, the change in the certificate of coverage, the impact of that is already reflected in your reduction of the exposure from $50 million to $35 million. Is that what you're referencing?
componenttext: So, Michael, the change in the certificate of coverage, the impact of that is already reflected in your reduction of the exposure from $50 million to $35 million. Is that what you're referencing?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that, yes, I think what you're going to see is you're going to see -- I mean, obviously the new certificates signed in effect until January 1. There were some changes they made effective earlier than that with a cut. But -- so we are starting to s
componenttext: I think that, yes, I think what you're going to see is you're going to see -- I mean, obviously the new certificates signed in effect until January 1. There were some changes they made effective earlier than that with a cut. But -- so we are starting to see where there's less people being translating to the no, they can no longer bill 75% of billed charges and -- I mean, there were instances where lab tests worth thousands of dollars, but we pay $8 for it.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, okay. Shifting to Medicare, if I could briefly. Curious if your reaction to the slight to modest decline in STAR scores for the Medicare book of business. What are your plans to boost those back up? And then maybe more broadly, your plans to begin
componenttext: Right, okay. Shifting to Medicare, if I could briefly. Curious if your reaction to the slight to modest decline in STAR scores for the Medicare book of business. What are your plans to boost those back up? And then maybe more broadly, your plans to begin to build track record in your new markets to have them be able to maintain a bonus level of STAR score?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll turn it over to Jesse in a minute. I want to remind you that there were 7 STAR scores that remained constant. There were 7 that improved. There was 1 that lost half a STAR because of the benefit change in the Part D drug, and it was in Oregon [indisc
componenttext: I'll turn it over to Jesse in a minute. I want to remind you that there were 7 STAR scores that remained constant. There were 7 that improved. There was 1 that lost half a STAR because of the benefit change in the Part D drug, and it was in Oregon [indiscernible] markets. So there was not a dramatic shift as some notes may have indicated. And Jesse, you want to pick it up to talk about the program?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I want to highlight a couple of things. One, in terms of the implications, I think some of the math that was referenced in a few of the notes that we saw included the dual members, D-SNP members in terms of the percentage of members that applied in v
componenttext: Yes, I want to highlight a couple of things. One, in terms of the implications, I think some of the math that was referenced in a few of the notes that we saw included the dual members, D-SNP members in terms of the percentage of members that applied in various kind of STAR levels. So I think there's a little bit mixing and matching with respect to that. But as Michael referenced, we did improve our STAR scores in a number of our plans, including our D-SNP plans, which are widely recognized to be more challenging to increase the STAR score. So we've demonstrated that we can do that. So we have a number of programs, not the least of which is provider engagement and how we're working with our providers in all these markets. And remember, when we were launching these new programs and as we referenced in Georgia, Texas, Florida, Mississippi, those are markets where we have long-standing provider relationships. So that will be a center point in terms of not only our kind of growth strategy but also our stars and quality improvement strategies going forward.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I wanted to just respond to second part of your question in terms of the new markets that the team that achieved these 4 and greater stars are the same team Health Net is working with us on a new market. And we have every reason to believe they'll use
componenttext: And I wanted to just respond to second part of your question in terms of the new markets that the team that achieved these 4 and greater stars are the same team Health Net is working with us on a new market. And we have every reason to believe they'll use the same processing approach to it that will achieve the high STAR levels.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: I appreciate the comments about 2017 and the fact that the disputed contracts in Pennsylvania are not in there for revenues. I know at one point, you were looking at it, absorbing some cost associated with that this year. And that was part of the $0.30, I think, or so of expansion cost. Can you comment on whether you've absorbed that this year? Is that going to be in next year's numbers? Or has that been delayed largely till next year? I know you have the LTS contract rolling out. Do you think the overall expansion number for next year will be more or less than the $0.30 you've incurred this year?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say at this point in time, Michael mentioned we're in the process of finalizing our AOPs and specifically with the timing of some of these awards, and obviously, that's one of the moving parts. So I'm not going to comment specifically on wha
componenttext: Well, I would say at this point in time, Michael mentioned we're in the process of finalizing our AOPs and specifically with the timing of some of these awards, and obviously, that's one of the moving parts. So I'm not going to comment specifically on what we expect for '17 on that front. But I will tell you that what we said today is that the costs for this year are actually higher in the fourth quarter. So yes, you're right, the change in that award status has reduced the level of cost associated with that. But then on the other side, we do expect significant growth in our marketplace business in '17, and we have seen an increase in startup cost of that in the fourth quarter.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. Then maybe a quick point on the PDR. So it now stands at $285 million. Tell us how that -- can you just give us some help on thinking about how that evolves over time? Do you expect -- since it relates to 2016, to run that down to 0 by th
componenttext: Okay, all right. Then maybe a quick point on the PDR. So it now stands at $285 million. Tell us how that -- can you just give us some help on thinking about how that evolves over time? Do you expect -- since it relates to 2016, to run that down to 0 by the end of the year? Do you -- will some of that carry over in case there's negative development from 2016 next year that you'll be able to offset? I guess, how should we think about how that plays out over the next period of time?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That will run down by the end of the year. Now specifically just on the substance abuse, I mean, ultimately, some of those end up in IBNR and they get paid from a cash perspective, they get paid next year. But the $285 million will run down to 0 by the en
componenttext: That will run down by the end of the year. Now specifically just on the substance abuse, I mean, ultimately, some of those end up in IBNR and they get paid from a cash perspective, they get paid next year. But the $285 million will run down to 0 by the end of this year.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And do you think there is -- will there any -- be any that gets carried over in case there's negative development on any of these items for next year?

componenttext: Well, the piece that will get carried over would be an IBNR, right? It would be in our medical -- yes, it'd be in our medical claims payable, right.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just then just the last quick question on -- you mentioned on the synergies on track and pleased with that. I know one aspect of the longer-term synergies you're evaluating was your pharmacy benefit status, both Health Net having one way, they were ap
componenttext: And just then just the last quick question on -- you mentioned on the synergies on track and pleased with that. I know one aspect of the longer-term synergies you're evaluating was your pharmacy benefit status, both Health Net having one way, they were approaching and you're doing it with your own PBM? Is there any update on where that all stands at this point, your thinking on that?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start. There's a blend really where we still have our PBM very active, and we use some of the things that Health Net was doing. And Jesse will give a little more color and granularity on it.
componenttext: Yes, I'll start. There's a blend really where we still have our PBM very active, and we use some of the things that Health Net was doing. And Jesse will give a little more color and granularity on it.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think the starting point here, A.J., is that we've -- one of our kind of core philosophies is serving a whole person. Obviously, pharmacy is part of that. So Centene is committed to the pharmacy business. So I think that's an important star
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think the starting point here, A.J., is that we've -- one of our kind of core philosophies is serving a whole person. Obviously, pharmacy is part of that. So Centene is committed to the pharmacy business. So I think that's an important starting point. And we -- as we look at our PBM, there's a number of things that we have developed and we think are core competencies, which includes benefit design, formulary management, clinical programs, analytics, mail order, specialty, et cetera. There's all of those things that are very much kind of embedded in how kind of the Centene pharmacy management model. We've also -- we'll be launching what we're going to rebranding is our external approach, which involves pharmacy solutions. Some of you may have seen a release that went out recently where we're going to be working with Mercer on some opportunities from an external perspective. But all of that said, Michael referenced the hybrid approach. So we have entered into an arrangement with CVS Caremark to really leverage some of the scale, particularly from a network perspective and certain back-office functions for pharmacists.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And does that increase your thinking on the synergies? Or is that sort of in line with what you had originally thought on the synergies?
componenttext: And does that increase your thinking on the synergies? Or is that sort of in line with what you had originally thought on the synergies?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In line with what we had originally thought on synergies.
componenttext: In line with what we had originally thought on synergies.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016

componenttext: The next question will come from Ralph Giacobbe of Citi.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to go back to the exchanges and your position for next year, just given market exits from peers. Any concerns around network adequacy? And then do you have any sort of enrollments caps in place at this point? And then just want to clarify, I thi
componenttext: Just want to go back to the exchanges and your position for next year, just given market exits from peers. Any concerns around network adequacy? And then do you have any sort of enrollments caps in place at this point? And then just want to clarify, I think in your prepared, you talked about Arizona, your expectation of $500 million of incremental revenue, I think, just from the exchange, which I think is about 140,000 lives back of the envelope. So are we still talking about a 25% increase in the exchange enrollment just from Arizona? So I guess, help sort of collaborate, I guess, those numbers. And then just in terms of how we think about capital in terms of all the new lives coming on next year.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, do you want to start on the capital?
componenttext: Jeff, do you want to start on the capital?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can handle the last question first, which is on capital. I mean, obviously Centene has been a very high growth company over the last 5 years. We've put over billions of dollars into capital at our subsidiaries. And we would expect, obviously, with
componenttext: Yes, I can handle the last question first, which is on capital. I mean, obviously Centene has been a very high growth company over the last 5 years. We've put over billions of dollars into capital at our subsidiaries. And we would expect, obviously, with this growth that we would have to contribute capital to fund the growth as well. However, I will tell you that on a percentage basis -- we've had years where we've had 50% growth. On a percentage basis, that growth is smaller when compared to the organization in total. So the capital requirements, a lot of those can be funded with free cash flow.

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just want to add to it. But as it relates to the growth, we're expecting significant growth -- and we'll give you more granularity in December at our Investor Day. But importantly, some people, I know, are worried about what you're going to pick up
componenttext: And I just want to add to it. But as it relates to the growth, we're expecting significant growth -- and we'll give you more granularity in December at our Investor Day. But importantly, some people, I know, are worried about what you're going to pick up some of the individuals or a high-cost plans. We think, one, we have our network. And if our network is advantageous to them, that's time to, let's say, well managed network. Secondly, we're a net payer of a lot of money, $300 million or so. So there is a safety net there within that amount, which approaches what some others said they've lost. So as I look -- we look at the exchanges going forward, we see ourselves in a very strong position to effectively grow it and still maintain the margins that we've become used to having. And you want to add anything to this?

headline: Centene Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, just specifically on your question, Ralph, around the network, just to further Michael's point, we are very focused on kind of network adequacy for the expected growth. But our orientation there is really we think we're fine in terms of facility-based
componenttext: No, just specifically on your question, Ralph, around the network, just to further Michael's point, we are very focused on kind of network adequacy for the expected growth. But our orientation there is really we think we're fine in terms of facility-based network. So our focus really is on physician services, particularly primary care.
